sp.p: turning round sharplyWho were they ? Out they go to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: That would n't be quite fair , would it , sir ? They 're young and thoughtless like .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: to himself rather than to herAfter all , it 's only what everybody else has been doing .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: It would n't be anything very bad that Master Bob has done ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: emphaticallyNo , Nanny . No . Nothing bad ; only — stupid .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I did n't know they put you in prison for being stupid . Some of us have been lucky .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: They can put you in prison for everything Nanny — being stupid or being wise , being bad or being good , being poor or — yes , or being rich .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: putting her last touches to the flowersThere ! Now it looks much more like what her ladyship 's used to . If you are n't sent to prison for being bad , it does n't seem to matter so much .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well — it is n't nice , you know .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: There 's lots of things that are n't nice in the world . They have n't come your way yet , and I only hope they never will .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I wish they had n't come Bob 's way .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Ah , Master Bob was born to meet them . Well , I 'll go up to her ladyship now .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , are they back ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Sir James and her ladyship came back from the police-station —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: The Old Bailey , Nanny .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: They came back about ten minutes ago , Master Gerald . And went up to their rooms .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Tell mother I 'm here , will you ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Yes , Sir .

div.stage: She goes out and comes back almost at once with PAMELA .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Here 's Miss Pamela .To PAMELAI was just saying that her ladyship will be down directly .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: smilingNot too directly now , Nanny .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: No , Master Gerald .Exit .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Pamela ! Have you just come up ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Mother and I are staying with Aunt Judith . Oh , Gerald ! Poor , poor Bob !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Have you seen him ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: He came down to us last week , and he has been writing the most heart-rending letters .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You 're a dear to be so good to him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: How can one help it ? Oh , Gerald , he has been stupid ! How he could have gone on as he did , hating it all , understanding nothing , but feeling all the time that things were wrong , and yet too proud or too obstinate to ask for help — had n't you any idea , any of you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: awkwardlyYou never could get him to talk about the City at all . If you asked him , he changed the subject .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: reproachfullyAh ! but how did you ask him ? Lightly ? Jokingly ? “ Hullo , Rothschild , how 's the City getting on ? ” That sort of way . You did n't really mind .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: smilingWell , if it comes to that , he did n't much mind how I was getting on at the Foreign Office . He never even said , “ Hullo , Grey , how are Balkans ? ”

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: You had plenty of people to say that ; Bob was different . I think I was the first person he really talked to about himself . That was before I met you . I begged him then to get out of it — little knowing . I wonder if it would have made any difference if you had gone up with him on — Oh , well , it does n't matter now .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: defensivelyWhat were you going to say ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Nothing .Looking at him thoughtfullyPoor Gerald ! it 's been bad for you too .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You 're not making it better by suggesting that I 've let Bob down in some way — I do n't quite know how .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: in distressOh , Gerald , do n't be angry with me — I do n't want to hurt you . But I can only think of Bob now . You 're so — you want so little ; Bob wants so much . Why does n't he come ? I sent a note round to his rooms to say that I 'd be here . Does n't he have lunch here ? Oh , Gerald , suppose the case is over , and they 've taken him to prison , and I 've never said good-bye to him . He said it would n't be over till this evening , but how would he know ? Oh , I can n't bear it if they 've taken him away , and his only friend never said good-bye to him .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Pamela , Pamela , do n't be so silly . It 's all right , dear ; of course I 'm not angry with you . And of course Bob will be here . I rang up Wentworth an hour ago , and he said the case can n't end till this evening .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: recoveringSorry , Gerald , I 'm being rather a fool .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: taking her handsYou 're being —There is a knock at the door , and he turns round impatientlyOh , what is it ?

div.stage: Enter MASON .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: handing noteThere 's a telephone message been waiting for you , sir . And her ladyship will be down directly .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Thank you , Nanny .Exit MASON .To PAMELAMay I ?He reads itOh , I say , this is rather — this is from Wentworth . He 's taken Bob round to lunch with him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: going towards the doorI must go , Gerald . Mr. Wentworth wo n't mind .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: stopping herLook here , dear , it 's going to be quite all right . Wentworth rang up from his rooms ; they 're probably halfway through lunch by now , and they 'll be round in ten minutes .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Supposing he does n't come ? Supposing he did n't get my note ? It may be waiting for him in his rooms now .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: All right , then , darling , I 'll ring him up .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: determinedNo . I 'll do it . Yes , Gerald , I know how to manage him . It is n't only that I must see him myself , but if —bravelyif the case is to be over this evening , and if what we fear is going to happen , he must — oh , he must say good-bye to his mother too .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , if that 's all , I 'll tell him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: He might n't come for you . He will for me ; No , Gerald ; I mean it . None of you understand him . I do .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But supposing he 's already started and you miss him ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I 'll telephone to him at his rooms . Oh , do n't stand there talking —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: opening the door for herOh , well ! But I think you 're —She has gone .

div.stage: He walks up and down the room absently , picking up papers and putting them down . MASON comes in and arranges the sofa R .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Miss Pamela gone , Master Gerald ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: She 's coming back .

div.stage: Enter LADY FARRINGDON .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: Oh , Gerald , I hoped you 'd be here .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: kissing herI 've only just got away . I could n't get round to the court .Seeing her to the sofaYou 're all right , dear ?Exit MASON .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: Now you 're here , Gerald . I telegraphed for Mason . She 's such a comfort . How nicely she 's done the flowers !She sits down on the sofa .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'm so glad you sent for her .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I do n't think your father —

div.stage: Enter SIR JAMES .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Ah , Gerald , I had to take your mother out . She was — ah — overcome . They have adjourned , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . The judge is summing up directly after lunch . Bob will be round here when he 's had something to eat .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: looking at his watchWell , I suppose we ought to try and eat something .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I could n't touch anything .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: going over to herPoor mother !

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: Oh , Gerald , could n't you do anything ? I 'm sure if you 'd gone into the witness-box , or told the judge — Oh , why did n't you go to the Bar , and then you could have defended him . You would have been so much better than that stupid man .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: I must say I did n't at all like his tone . He 's practically making out my son to be an idiot .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , it 's really the only line he could take .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: What do you mean ? Bob is far from being an idiot .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: We always knew he was n't as clever as Gerald , dear .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You see , Bob either understood what was going on or he did n't . If he did , then he 's in it as much as Marcus . If he did n't — well , of course we know that he did n't . But no doubt the jury will think that he ought to have known .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: The old story , a knave or a fool , eh ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: The folly was in sending him there .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: angrilyThat was Parkinson 's fault . It was he who recommended Marcus to me . I shall never speak to that man again .To his wifeMary , if the Parkinsons call , you are out ; remember that .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: He never ought to have gone into business at all . Why could n't you have had him taught farming or estate agency or something ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: We 've got to move with the times , my boy . Land is played out as a living for gentlemen ; they go into business nowadays . If he can n't get on there , it 's his own fault . He went to Eton and Oxford ; what more does he want ?

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: to GERALDYou must remember he is n't clever like you , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , well , it 's no good talking about it now . Poor old Bob ! Wentworth thinks —

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Ah , now why could n't Wentworth have defended him ? That other man — why , to begin with , I do n't even call him a gentleman .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Wentworth recommended him . But I wish he had gone to Wentworth before , as soon as he knew what was coming .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Why did n't he come to me ? Why did n't he come to any of us ? Then we might have done something .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: Did n't he even tell you , Gerald ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: awkwardlyOnly just at the last . It was — it was too late to do anything then . It was the Saturday before he was — arrested .To himself“ The Saturday before Bob was arrested ” — what a way to remember anything by !

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: to GERALDBob is coming round , dear ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . Wentworth 's looking after him . Pamela will be here too .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: We have n't seen much of Pamela lately . What does she think about it ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: sharplyWhat do you mean ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: The disgrace of it . I hope it 's not going to affect your engagement .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Disgrace ? what disgrace ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Well , of course , he has n't been found guilty yet .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What 's that got to do with it ? What does it matter what a lot of rotten jurymen think of him ? We know that he has done nothing disgraceful .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I 'm sure Pamela would n't think anything like that of your brother , dear .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course she would n't . She 's been a perfect angel to Bob these last few weeks . What does it matter if he does go to prison ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: I suppose you think I shall enjoy telling my neighbours , when they ask me what my elder boy is doing , that he 's — ah — in prison .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course you wo n't enjoy it , and I do n't suppose Bob will enjoy it either , but that 's no reason why we should make it worse for him by pretending that he 's a disgrace to the family .Half to himselfIf anything we 've done has helped to send him to prison then it 's we who should be ashamed .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: I do n't profess to know anything about business , but I flatter myself that I understand my fellow men . If I had been in Bob 's place , I should have pretty soon seen what that fellow Marcus was up to . I do n't want to be unfair to Bob ; I do n't think that any son of mine would do a dishonourable action ; but the Law is the Law , and if the Law sends Bob to prison I can n't help feeling the disgrace of it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , it 's rough on you and mother .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I do n't mind about myself , dear . It 's you I feel so sorry for — and Bob , of course .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I do n't see how it 's going to affect me .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: In the Foreign Office one has to be like Caesar 's wife — above suspicion .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , but in this case it 's Caesar 's brother-in-law 's partner who 's the wrong un . I do n't suppose Caesar was so particular about him .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I do n't see how Caesar comes into it at all .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: kindlyI spoke in metaphors , dear .

div.stage: The door opens and WENTWORTH appears .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Come in , Wentworth . Where 's Bob ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: I dropped him at his rooms — a letter or something he wanted to get . But he 'll be here directly .NervouslyHow do you do , Lady Farringdon ? How do you do , Sir James ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Ah , Wentworth .

div.stage: There is an awkward silence and nobody seems to know what to say .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Very hot this morning .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Very hot . Very .

div.stage: There is another awkward silence .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: This is quite a good hotel . My mother always stays here when she 's in London .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Ah , yes . We use it a good deal ourselves .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: How is Mrs. Wentworth ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: She 's been keeping very well this summer , thank you .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I 'm so glad .

div.stage: There is another awkward silence .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: impatientlyOh , what 's the good of pretending this is a formal call , Wentworth ? Tell us about Bob ; how 's he taking it ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: He does n't say much . He had lunch in my rooms — you got my message . He could n't bear the thought of being recognized by anyone , so I had something sent up .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: realizing what it must feel likePoor old Bob !

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Lady Farringdon , I can n't possibly tell you what I feel about this , but I should like to say that all of us who know Bob know that he could n't do anything dishonourable . Whatever the result of the trial , we shall feel just the same towards him .

div.stage: LADY FARRINGDON is hardly able to acknowledge this , and SIR JAMES goes across to comfort her .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: helplesslyThere , there , Mary .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: seizing his opportunity , to WENTWORTHWhat 'll he get ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: quietlyThree months — six months . One can n't be certain .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: cheering upThank the Lord ! I imagined awful things .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: his ministrations overAfter all , he has n't been found guilty yet ; eh , Wentworth ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Certainly , Sir James . With a jury there 's always hope .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: What do you think yourself ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: I think he has been very foolish ; whether the Law will call it criminally foolish I should hardly like to say . I only wish I had known about it before . He must have suspected something — did n't he say anything to anybody ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: He told Gerald , apparently . For some reason he preferred to keep his father in the dark .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: eagerlyThat was the day you came down to us , Wentworth ; five days before he was arrested . I asked him to tell you , but he would n't .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Oh , it was too late then . Marcus had absconded by that time .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: earnestlyNobody could have helped him then , could they ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Oh no .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: to himselfThank God .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: to LADY FARRINGDON as he looks at his watchWell , dear , I really think you ought to try to eat something .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: I could n't , James .Getting upBut you must have your lunch .

lg.l: Well , one ought n't to neglect one 's health , of course . But
I insist on your having a glass of claret anyhow , Mary . What about you ,
Gerald ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'm all right . I 'll wait for Bob . I 've had something .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: You wo n't let Bob go without seeing us ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course not , dear .

div.stage: He goes with them to the door and sees them out .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: coming back to WENTWORTHThree months . By Jove ! that 's nothing .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: It 's long enough for a man with a grievance . It gives him plenty of time to brood about it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: anxiouslyWho has Bob got a grievance against particularly ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: The world .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: relievedAh ! Still , three months , Wentworth . I could do it on my head .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: You 're not Bob . Bob will do it on his heart .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: We must buck him up , Wentworth . If he takes it the right way , it 's nothing . I had awful thoughts of five years .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: I 'm not the judge , you know . It may be six months .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course . How does he decide ? Tosses up for it ? Three months or six months or six years , it 's all the same to him , and there 's the poor devil in the dock praying his soul out that he 'll hit on the shortest one . Good Lord ! I 'm glad I 'm not a judge .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: drilyYes ; that is n't quite the way the Law works .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not blaming the Law .SmilingStick to it , Wentworth , by all means . But I should make a bad judge . I should believe everything the prisoner said , and just tell him not to do it again .

div.stage: BOB comes in awkwardly and stops at the door .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: getting upCome along , Bob .Taking out his caseHave a cigarette .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: grufflyNo , thanks .He takes out his pipe .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: brightly but awkwardlyHullo , Bob , old boy .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Where 's Pamela ? She said she 'd be here .He sits down in the large armchair .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If she said she 'd be here , she will be here .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: with a grunt‘ M !There is an awkward silence .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: angrily to GERALDWhy do n't you say something ? You came here to say good-bye to me , I suppose — why do n't you say it ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Steady , Bob .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: eagerlyLook here , Bob , old son , you must n't take it too hardly . Wentworth thinks it will only be three months — do n't you , Wentworth ? You know , we none of us think any the worse of you for it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Thanks . That will console me a lot in prison .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , Bob , do n't be an old fool . You know what I mean . You have done nothing to be ashamed of , so what 's the good of brooding in prison , and grousing about your bad luck , and all that sort of thing ? If you had three months in bed with a broken leg , you 'd try and get some sort of satisfaction out of it — well , so you can now if you try .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: after waiting for BOB to say somethingThere 's a good deal in that , Bob , you know . Prison is largely what you make it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: What do either of you know about it ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Everything . The man with imagination knows the best and the worst of everything .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: fiercelyImagination ? You think I have n't imagined it ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Wentworth 's right . You can make what you like of it . You can be miserable anywhere , if you let yourself be . You can be happy anywhere , if you try to be .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: to lead him onI can n't quite see myself being actually happy in prison , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I could , Wentworth , I swear I could .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: He 'd get popular with the warders ; he 'd love that .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: smilingSilly old ass ! But there are lots of things one can do in prison , only no one ever seems to think of them .He gets interested and begins to walk up and down the room .Now take this solitary confinement there 's so much fuss about . If you look at it the right way , there 's nothing in it at all .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: A bit boring , perhaps .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Boring ? Nonsense . You 're allowed one book a week from the prison library , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: You know , you must n't think that , because I 'm a barrister , I know all about the inside of a prison .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , suppose you are allowed one , and you choose a French dictionary , and try to learn it off by heart before you come out . Why , it 's the chance of a lifetime to learn French .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: Well , of course , if you could get a French dictionary —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , there 'd be some book there anyway . If it 's a Bible , read it . When you 've read it , count the letters in it ; have little bets with yourself as to which man 's name is mentioned most times in it ; put your money on Moses and see if you win . Anything like that . If it 's a hymn-book , count how many of the rhymes rhyme and how many do n't ; try and make them all rhyme . Learn ‘ em by heart ; I do n't say that that would be particularly useful to you in the business world afterwards , but it would be amusing to see how quickly you could do it , how many you could keep in your head at the same time .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: This is too intellectual for me ; my brain would go in no time .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You are n't doing it all day , of course ; there are other things . Physical training . Swedish exercises . Tell yourself that you 'll be able to push up fifty times from the ground before you come out . Learn to walk on your hands . Practise cart-wheels , if you like . Gad ! you could come out a Hercules .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: I can n't help feeling that the strain of improving myself so enormously would tell on me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , you 'd have your games and so on to keep you bright and jolly .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: sarcasticallyGolf and cricket , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Golf , of course ; I 'm doubtful about cricket . You must have another one for cricket , and I 'm afraid the warder would n't play . But golf , and squash rackets , and bowls , and billiards — and croquet —

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: in despairOh , go on !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Really , you 're hopeless . What the Swiss Family Wentworth would have done if they 'd ever been shipwrecked , I can n't think . Do n't you ever invent anything for yourself ?ExcitedlyMan alive ! you 've got a hymn-book and a piece of soap , what more do you want ? You can play anything with that .ThoughtfullyOh , I forgot the Olympic games . Standing long jump . And they talk about the boredom of it !

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: thoughtfullyYou 've got your ideas , Gerald . I wonder if you 'd act up to them .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: One never knows , but honestly I think so .There is silence for a little .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Is that all ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , Bob , I know it 's easy for me to talk —

lg.l: I wonder you did n't say at once : “ Try not to think about it . ”
You 're always helpful .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You 're a little difficult to help , you know Bob .AwkwardlyI thought I might just give you an idea . If I only could help you , you know how —

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: doggedlyI asked you to help me once .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: distressedOh , I did n't realize then — besides , Wentworth says it would have been much too late — did n't you , Wentworth ?

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: taking up his hatI think I must be getting along now .Holding out his handGood-bye , Bob . I can only say , “ The best of luck , ” and — er — whatever happens , you know what I feel about it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: shaking his handGood-bye , Wentworth , and thanks very much for all you 've done for me .

sp.speaker: WENTWORTH
sp.p: hurriedlyThat 's all right .TO GERALD , quietly , as he passes him on the way to the doorYou must bear with him , Gerald . Naturally he 's —NoddingGood-bye .He goes out .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: going back to BOBBob —

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Why does n't Pamela come ? I want Pamela .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: speaking quicklyLook here , think what you like of me for the moment . But you must listen to what I 've got to say . You can imagine it 's somebody else speaking Pamela , if you like — Pamela would say just the same . You must not go to prison and spend your time there brooding over the wrongs people have done to you , and the way the world has treated you , and all that sort of thing . You simply must make an effort — and — and — well , come out as good a man as you went in . I know it 's easy for me to talk , but that does n't make it any the less true . Oh , Bob , be a — be a Sportsman about it ! You can take it out of me afterwards , if you like , but do n't take it out of me now by — by not bucking up just because I suggest it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I want Pamela . Why does n't she come ?

div.stage: PAMELA has come in while he is saying this .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Here I am , Bob .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: getting upAt last ! I began to be afraid you were never coming .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: You could n't think that . I told you I was coming .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Look here , Pamela , we 've got to cheer old Bob up .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: almost shoutingGood Lord ! can n't you see that I do n't want you ? I want Pamela alone .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: putting her hand on GERALD 'S shoulderGerald , dear , you must n't be angry with Bob now . Let me be alone with him .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: with a shrugAll right . Poor old Bob !He goes over to his brother and holds out his hand .Good-bye , old boy , and — good luck .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: coldlyGood-bye .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Shake hands , Bob .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: No . I 've been nothing to you all your life . You could have saved me from this , and you would n't help me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: angrilyDo n't talk such rot !

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: coming between themGerald , dear , you 'd better go . Bob wo n't always feel like this towards you , but just now —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: indignantlyPamela , you do n't believe this about me ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I can n't think of you , dear , now ; I can only think of Bob .GERALD gives a shrug and goes out .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Pamela .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: coming to himYes , dear ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Come and sit near me . You 're the only friend I 've got in the world .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: You know that is n't true .

div.stage: She sits down in the armchair and he sits on the floor at her feet .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: If it had n't been for you , I should have shot myself long ago .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: That would have been rather cowardly , would n't it ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I am a coward . There 's something about the Law that makes people cowards . It 's so — what 's the word ? It goes on . You can n't stop it , you can n't explain to it , you can n't even speak to it .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: But you can stand up to it . You need n't run away from it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I think I would have broken my bail and run , if it had n't been for you . But you would have thought less of me if I had . Besides , I should n't have seen you again .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Bob , you must n't just do , or not do , things for me ; you must do them because of yourself . You must be brave because it 's you , and honourable because it 's you , and cheerful because it 's you . You must n't just say , “ I wo n't let Pamela down . ” You must say , “ I wo n't let myself down . ” You must be proud of yourself .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: bitterlyI 've been taught to be proud of myself , have n't I ? Proud of myself ! What 's the family creed ? “ I believe in Gerald . I believe in Gerald the Brother . I believe in Gerald the Son . I believe in Gerald the Nephew . I believe in Gerald the Friend , the Lover , Gerald the Holy Marvel . ” There may be brothers who do n't mind that sort of thing , but not when you 're born jealous as I was . Do you think father or mother cares a damn what happens to me ? They 're upset , of course , and they feel the disgrace for themselves , but the belovèd Gerald is all right , and that 's all that really matters .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Bob , dear , forget about Gerald now . Do n't think about him ; think about yourself .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I sha n't think about myself or about Gerald when I 'm in prison . I shall only think of you .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Will it help you to think of me ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You 're the only person in the world I 've got to think of . I found you first — and then Gerald took you from me . Just as he 's always taken everything from me .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: No , no . Not about Gerald again . Let 's get away from Gerald .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You can n't . He 's a devil to get away from .There is silence for a little .When I was a small boy , I used to pray very hard on the last day of the holidays for a telegram to come saying that the school had been burnt down .... It never had .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh , Bob !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I suppose I 've got about ten minutes more . But nothing will happen .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: in a hopeless effort to be hopefulPerhaps after all you might —

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Why can n't the world end suddenly now ? It would n't matter to anybody . They would n't know ; they would n't have time to understand .He looks up and sees her face of distress and saysAll right , Pamela , you need n't worry . I 'm going through with it all right .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: You must keep thinking of the afterwards . Only of the afterwards . The day when you come back to us .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Will that be such a very great day ?PAMELA is silent .Triumphant procession through the village . All the neighbours hurrying out to welcome the young squire home . Great rush in the City to offer him partnerships .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: quietlyDo you want to go back to the City ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Good God , no !

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Then why are you being sarcastic about it ? Be honest with yourself , Bob . You made a mess of the City . Oh , I know you were n't suited to it , but men have had to do work they did n't like before now , and they have n't all made a mess of it . You 're getting your punishment now — much more than you deserve , and we 're all sorry for you — but men have been punished unfairly before now and they have stood it . You 'll have your chance when you come back ; I 'll stand by you for one , and you 've plenty of other friends ; but we can n't help a man who wo n't help himself , you know . BonsulkilyThank you , Pamela .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: shaking himBob , Bob , do n't be such a baby . Oh , I want to laugh at you , and yet my heart just aches for you . You 're just a little boy , Bobwith a sigh, on the last day of his holidays .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: after a pauseAre you allowed to have letters in prison ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I expect so . Every now and then .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You will write to me ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Of course , dear ; whenever I may .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I suppose some beast will read it . But you wo n't mind that , will you ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: No , dear .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I 'll write to you whenever they let me . That will be something to look forward to . Will you meet me when I come out ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: happilyYes , Bob . So very gladly .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I 'll let you know when it is . I expect I 'll be owed to .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: You must just think of that day all the time . Whenever you are unhappy or depressed or angry , you must look forward to that day .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You 'll let it be a fine day , wo n't you ? What shall we do ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: rather startledWhat ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: What shall we do directly after I come out ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Well , I suppose we — I mean you — well , we 'll come up to London together , I suppose , and you 'll go to your old rooms . At least , if you still have them .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: instantly depressed againMy old rooms . That 'll be lively .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Well , unless you 'd rather —

lg.l: I 'm not going home , if that 's what you mean . The prodigal son , and
Gerald falling on my neck .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: stroking his headNever mind Gerald , Baby .He turns round suddenly and seizes her hands .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: in a rushWhatever happens , you must n't desert me when I come out . I want you . I 've got to know you 're there , waiting for me . I 'm not making love to you , you 're engaged to somebody else , but you were my friend before you were his , and you 've got to go on being my friend . I want you — I want you more than he does . I 'm not making love to you ; you can marry him if you like , but you 've got to stand by me . I want you .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Have n't I stood by you ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: in a low voiceYou 've been an angel .He kisses her hands and then gets up and walks away from her ; with his back to her , looking out of the window , he saysWhen are you marrying him ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: taken by surpriseI — I do n't know , Bob . We had thought about — but , of course , things are different now . We have n't talked about it lately .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: casuallyI wonder if you 'd mind promising me something .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Not to get married till after I come out .After waiting for PAMELA to speakYou will have about forty years together afterwards . It is n't much to ask .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Why should it make a difference to you ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: It would .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: It is n't a thing I like making promises about . But I do n't suppose for a moment — Would it help you very much , Bob ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: from the bottom of his heartI do n't want Gerald 's wife to be waiting for me when I come out ; I want my friend .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: standing up and facing him as he turns round towards herAll right , Bob , she shall be there .

div.stage: They stand looking at each other intently for a moment . Voices are heard outside , and SIR JAMES , LADY FARRINGDON , and GERALD come into the room .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: [ SCENE .— In the hall at SIR JAMES FARRINGDON 'S again . It is autumn nom and there is a fire burning . ]
[ LETTY and TOMMY are on the sofa side by side , holding hands , and looking the picture of peaceful happiness . Indeed , TOMMY has his mouth open slightly . ]

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: It 's your turn to say something , Tommy .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: Oh , I say .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Now I suppose it 's my turn .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I say , you know , I feel too idiotically happy to say anything . I feel I want to talk poetry , or rot like that , only — only I do n't quite know how to put it .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: sympatheticallyNever mind , darling .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I say , you do understand how frightfully — I say , what about another kiss ?They have one .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Tommy , I just adore you . Only I think you might have been a little more romantic about your proposal .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: anxiousI say , do you —

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Yes . Strictly speaking , I do n't think anybody ought to propose with a niblick in his hand .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: It just sort of came then . Of course I ought to have put it down .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: You dear !... “ Letting his niblick go for a moment , Mr. T. Todd went on as follows : ‘ Letitia , my beloved , many moons have waxed and waned since first I cast eyes of love upon thee . An absence of ducats , coupled with the necessity of getting my handicap down to ten , has prevented my speaking ere this . Now at last I am free . My agèd uncle — ’ ”

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: lovinglyI say , you do pull my leg . Go on doing it always , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Always , Tommy . We 're going to have fun , always .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I 'm awfully glad we got engaged down here .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: We 've had lovely times here , have n't we ?

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I wonder what Gerald will say . A bit of a surprise for him . I say , it would be rather fun if we had a double wedding . You and I , and Gerald and Pamela .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: getting up in pretended indignationCertainly not !

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: following herI say , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: waving him backGo away . Unhand me villain .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I say , what 's up ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: I want a wedding of my own . I 've never been married before , and perhaps I shall never be married again , and I 'm going to have a wedding all to myself . I do n't mind your being there , but I 'm not going to have crowds of other brides and bridegrooms taking up the whole aisle — said she , seizing her engagement-ring and — Oh , bother ! I have n't got one yet .

div.stage: TOMMY rushes up and takes her in his arms . At this moment GERALD comes in by the garden door . He stops on seeing them , and then goes quickly on to the door in front of the staircase .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: as he passes themCame in and went tactfully out again .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: as LETTY frees herselfI say , Gerald , old man .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: stopping at the door , turning round and coming back in the same business-like wayReturned hopefully .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: in confusionI say , we 're engaged .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: looking at them happilyOh , hoo-ray !

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Do say you 're surprised .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Awfully , awfully pleased , Letty . Of course , when I saw you — er — thinking together in a corner — By Jove , I am bucked . I did hope so much .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: You dear !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I feel very fatherly . Bless you , my children .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: We shall have about tuppence a year , but Letty does n't mind that .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: to LETTYYou 'll have to make him work .ThoughtfullyHe 's too old for a caddy .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Could n't you find him something in the Foreign Office ? He knows the French for pen and ink .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: What 's ink ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: At least , he knows the French for pen .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , we 'll find something . Only I warn you , Tommy , if you dare to get married before Pamela and me , there 'll be trouble .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: Why do n't we ever see Pamela now ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: gailyShe is coming , my children — mes enfants , as Tommy will say when he gets his job as ribbon starcher to the French ambassador . To-morrow , no less . I 've just had a letter . Lord , I have n't seen her for months .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: She 's come back ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . Egypt knows her no more . The Sphinx is inconsolable . To-morrow at 3. 30 she comes ; I shall go and meet her .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I say , wo n't she be surprised about Letty and me !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: She 'll be as bucked as I am .Looking from one to the otherHas anything else frightfully exciting happened to you since lunch ? Because , if not , I 've got some more news .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: What is it ? I love news .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: All ready ? Then one , two , three : Bob is coming this afternoon .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: and TOMMY together . No ! Rot !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Singing to the tune of “ Here we go gathering nuts and may ”Oh , Bob is coming this afternoon , this afternoon , this afternoon ! Oh , Bob is coming this afternoon , all on an autumn morning ! Now then , all together .

div.stage: They join hands and march up the hall and back again , singing together .

sp.speaker: ALL TOGETHER
sp.p: waving imaginary hatsHooray ! Hooray ! Hooray !

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: It does n't make sense , you know , coming back in the afternoon on an autumn morning .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Who cares for sense ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: squeezing his armOh , Gerald , I am glad . But I thought he had another week or so .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: They always let you out early , you know , if you 're good . We knew he was coming soon , but we did n't quite know when . I 've just had a telegram .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Poor Bob ! he must have had a time .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What does it matter ? It 's over now .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: struck by an ideaI say , this puts a bit of a stopper on our news .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: pulled up suddenly by thisOh !

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: going over and taking TOMMY 'S armWe 'll go to a house where they do make a fuss of us , Tommy .Very politelyGood-bye , Mr. Farringdon , and thank you for a very pleasant Friday .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Poor darlings ! it 's rather bad luck for you . Did I announce my news too soon ? I 'm awfully sorry .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: It was n't your fault ; you were a dear .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: As a matter of fact , it will be rather lucky , you know . It will give us something to talk about when Bob comes .SmilingThanks very much for arranging it .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Poor old Bob ! I wonder what it feels like coming out of prison .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Rotten . Now , for the Lord 's sake , Tommy , be tactful .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: to GERALDI think he 'd be safer if he was n't . Tommy 's rather dangerous when he 's tactful .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: thoughtfullyYes , there is that .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: It 's all the same to me . Only just let me know which you want .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , as long as you do n't overdo it . Do n't rub it in that he 's just left prison , and — do n't rub it out .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I suppose it would be quite safe to ask him to pass the mustard ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: laughingGood old Tommy !

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: You 'd better talk to me all the time , and then you 'll be all right .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: We 'll make it go between us . And , of course , Pamela will help to-morrow . Hooray for Pamela ! It makes me quite envious seeing you young people together . By the way , I interrupted you just now .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: You did rather .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , I absolutely refuse to go away now . But , of course , if you 're longing to show each other the stables or anything —with a wave of the handpray show . Or try anywhere else . Save for Aunt Tabitha 's room upstairs and the hall down here , the whole house is at your disposal .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: sitting down firmlyThen I shall stay here . Is n't Aunt Mary back yet ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: They are probably still eating . It 's the very latest millionaire from London , so they 're having the lunch of their lives , I expect . Afterwards father will put him at his ease by talking about crops .Picking up a book and settling himself comfortably in front of the fireTommy , if you can n't find a book , sing or something .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Oh , come on , Tommy .

div.stage: She jumps up and goes out of the door in front of the staircase . TOMMY following her .

Left alone , GERALD closes his book with a slam . He stands up and takes the telegram out of his pocket and reads it again . He suddenly catches sight of MISS FARRINGDON in the gallery shove , calls out “ Hullo ! ” and goes up the stairs to meet her .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: as he goesYou 're just the person I wanted , Aunt Tabitha . I 'm full of news .He kisses her at the top of the stairs .How are you , dear ?He offers her his arm .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: If I had wanted help , down the stairs , Gerald , my maid could have given it me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , but your maid would n't have enjoyed giving it you ; I do .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Charming Gerald .She comes down the stairs on his arm .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No , happy Gerald .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Is that part of the news ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It 's all because of the news .

div.stage: He arranges her in her chair by the fire and sits on the coffin-stool near her .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: I heard Mr. Todd and Letty just now , so I suppose I sha n't be the first to hear it . What a pity !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Ah , but they do n't count .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , that 's part of the news . They 've just got engaged .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: In my young days they 'd have been engaged a long time ago . When are we going to see Pamela again ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That 's more of the news . She 's coming down to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: That will save you a lot in stamps .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: laughingAunt Tabitha , you 're a witch . How did you know ?

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Know what ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That Pamela and I have n't been writing to each other .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: very innocentlyHave n't you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No . You see — oh , I hate discussing Pamela with anyone , but you 're different .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: I always like that sort of compliment best , Gerald . The unintended sort .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I think , you know , Pamela felt that Bob 's doing to prison might make a difference . I do n't mean that she did n't like the disgrace for herself , but that she was afraid that I might n't like it for her ; and so she went away , and beyond a letter or two at the start there has n't been a Pamela .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: But Gerald went on being successful ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , Aunt Tabitha , Aunt Tabitha , if ever I were going to be conceited — and I do n't think I am really — you 'd soon stop it , would n't you ? I wonder if you do know me as well as you think . You think I 'm all outside , do n't you , and inside there 's nothing ?

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Oh , you 've got brains , I 'll grant you that . You 're the first Farringdon that 's had any . Of the men , of course .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , brains — I do n't mean brains . But you think that everything only touches me on the surface , and that nothing ever goes deep inside . You do n't believe I ever loved Pamela ; you do n't believe I love her now . You do n't believe I 've got a heart at all .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Well , you 've never shown it . You 've shown a lot of delightful things which silly people mistake for it — but that 's all .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: curtlyNo , I 've never shown my heart to anybody . Some people can n't .GentlyPerhaps I 'll show it to Pamela on my wedding-day .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Dear me , have I been wrong all these years ? I should n't like to think that .After a pauseAny more news ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: taking his thoughts off PAMELAYes . Now this time , Aunt Tabitha , you 'll really be as pleased as I am .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: I wonder .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh yes , you will , because it 's about your favourite — Bob .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: So Bob 's my favourite ? I 'm learning a good many things to-day .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: He 's coming back this afternoon .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Poor Bob ! I 'm glad he 's finished with that part of it .

lg.l: You think he 's got the worst part coming ?
Aunt
Tabitha , have you got any influence with your nephew ?

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: You or Bob ?GERALD smiles and shakes his head .Oh , you mean James ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It seems hard to realize that one 's father is anybody else 's nephew , but you are his aunt , and — Oh , do n't let him do anything stupid about Bob .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Bob 's his own master ; he 's old enough to look after himself .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , but he 's got in the way of being looked after by other people . I wish you would look after him and tell him what to do . It 's going to be difficult for him . I expect he 'll want to get away from all of us for a bit . Where 's he going , and what 's he going to do ?

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: after a pauseWhen did you say Pamela was coming here ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: To-morrow . She 'll help , of course .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Gerald , you 've been very nice to me always ; I do n't know why I 've been rather unkind to you sometimes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What an idea ! You know I 've loved our little skirmishes .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: That 's because you 've been happy , and have n't minded one way or another . But if ever you were in trouble , Gerald , I do n't think I should be unsympathetic .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You dear , of course you would n't . But why do you say that now , just when I am so happy ?

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: getting up slowlyI 'm feeling rather an old woman to-day . I think I 'll go and lie down .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: jumping upI 'll ring for your maid .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: No , no ; I 'm not going upstairs , and I do n't want a maid when I 've got a great big nephew . Come and tuck me up on the sofa in the drawing-room ; I shall be quite happy there .

div.stage: She puts her hand on his arm , and they go together towards the door in front of the staircase .

sp.speaker: MISS FARRINGDON
sp.p: Poor Gerald !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: laughingWhy poor ?They go out together .

div.stage: The door on the right at the back opens quietly and BOB comes in . He stands there for a moment looking at the hall , and then speaks over his shoulder to somebody behind him .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: It 's all right , there 's nobody here .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I wonder where Gerald is .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You 're sure he 's down here ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Yes , I had a letter from him ; he told me he was going to be .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: going up to herPamela , you can n't see him alone .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I must . You can see him afterwards , but I must see him alone first . Poor Gerald !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: He never really loved you .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I do n't think he did really , but it will hurt him .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: eagerlySay you 're not sorry for what you 're doing .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Are n't I doing it ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Say you love me and not Gerald . Say you really love me , and it 's not just because you are sorry for me .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh , I have so much in my heart for you , Bob . I 'm glad I 'm marrying you . But you must always love me , and want me as you want me now .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: seizing her is his armsBy God ! you 'll get that .He kisses her fiercely .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: satisfiedOh , Bob ! Oh , Bob ! I 'm glad I found you at last .She goes away from him and stands looking into the fire , one hand on the mantelpiece .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Shall I go and look for Gerald ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: looking into the fireYes . No . He 'll come .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You wo n't let him talk you round ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: looking up at him in surpriseOh no ; I 'm quite safe now .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I can never thank you for all you 've done , for all you 've been to me . When we are out of this cursèd country , and I have you to myself , I will try to show you .She says nothing , and he walks restlessly about the room . He picks up a hat and saysHullo , Tommy 's here .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: quicklyI do n't want to see him , I do n't want to see anybody . We must just tell Gerald and then go .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Anybody might come at any moment . You should have let me write as I wanted to . Or waited till he came back to London .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: We 've given up being cowards . Perhaps you 'd better try and find him . We 'll only tell Gerald . If we see the others , we 'll just have to make the best of it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: moving off towards the door in front of the staircaseAll right . If I find him I 'll send him in here .He goes out .

div.stage: PAMELA drops into a chair and remains looking at the fire . GERALD , coming down from the gallery above , suddenly catches sight of her .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: rushing down the stairsPamela ! Why , Pamela !ExcitedlyWhy are you — You said tomorrow . Pamela , you said — Never mind , you 're here . Oh , bless you !PAMELA has got up to meet him , and he is now standing holding her hands , and looking at her happily .Pamela 's here ; all 's right with the world .He leans forward to kiss her , but she stops him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: nervouslyNo , no ; I 've something to tell you , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 've got a thousand things to tell you .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Bob 's here .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: excitedBob ? Did you come down with him ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I had a telegram , but it did n't say — Did you meet him ? Why did n't he tell us ? Where is he ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: He just went to look for you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'll soon find him .

div.stage: He turns away to go after BOB , but PAMELA stops him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Gerald !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: turning roundYes .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Never mind Bob for the moment . I wanted to see you alone .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: coming back quicklyOf course . Hang Bob ! Come on the sofa and tell me everything . Jove ! it 's wonderful to see you again ; you 've been away for years .

div.stage: He takes her hand and tries to lead her towards the sofa , but she stops .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Gerald , you 're making it very hard for me ; I 've got something to tell you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: afraid suddenly and speaking sharplyWhat do you mean ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh , do n't look at me like that — I know it will hurt you , but it wo n't be more than that . I want you to release me from my promise .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What promise ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: in a low voiceMy promise to marry you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I do n't understand . Why ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: bravelyI want to marry Bob .

div.stage: Keeping his eyes on her all the time , GERALD moves slowly away from her .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: to himselfBob ! Bob ! But you knew Bob first .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: And then you promised to marry me . You could n't have been in love with him . I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: sadlyI do n't understand either , but that 's how it 's happened .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: And to think how I 've been throwing you in Bob 's way , and wanting you and him to be fond of each other .FiercelyThat did n't make you think that I did n't love you ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: falteringI — I do n't — you did n't —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I was so confident of you . That was your fault . You made me .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I think you could have made me love you if you had n't been so confident .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I trusted you . You had told me . I knew I should never change , and I thought I knew you would n't .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I was wrong . I never did love you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Then why did you say —

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: looking at him rather wistfullyYou 're rather charming , Gerald , you know , and you —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: turning away from her furiouslyDamn charming ! That 's what you all say . I 'm sick of it ! You think that if a man 's charming , that 's the end of him , and that all he 's good for is to amuse a few old ladies at a tea party . I 'm sick of it ! The rude rough man with the heart of gold — that 's the only sort that can have a heart at all , according to some of you .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: utterly surprised by thisGerald !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'm sorry , Pamela . Of course you would n't understand . But we were just talking .With a sudden disarming smileI do n't know whether an apology is overdoing the charm ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: in distressOh , Gerald , you could n't really have loved me ; you do n't really now . Of course , it will hurt you , but you 'll soon get over it . Oh , what 's the good of my talking like this ? I 've never really known you ; I do n't know you now .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: quietlyIt 's no good now , anyway .He walks away from her and looks out through the windows at the back .Just tell me one or two things . Were you in love with him when he went to prison ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I do n't know — really I do n't know . I was so dreadfully sorry for him all that time before , and I felt so very friendly towards him , so very — oh , Gerald , so motherly . And I wanted to be wanted so badly , and you did n't seem to want me in that way . That was why , when he had gone , I went right away from you , and asked you not to write to me ; I wanted to think it all out — alone .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But you wrote to Bob ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh , Gerald , he wanted it so badly .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I wrote to him and he wrote to me . I met him when he came out — he told me when to come . I suppose I had decided by then ; we came down here to tell you . I had to come at once .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You do love him , Pamela ? It is n't just pity ?

lg.l: I do , Gerald ; I think I found that out this afternoon .
Say you do n't hate me very much .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I wish to God I could .... What are you and Bob going to do ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Canada , as soon as we can . I 've got friends there . We 've a little money between us . Bob ought to have done it a long time ago .Coming up to himJust do one more nice thing for me before we go .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: moving away from her on pretence of getting a cigaretteWhat is it ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Bob will want to see you before he goes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I do n't want to see him .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Ah , but you must .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What have we got to say to each other ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: I do n't know , but I feel you must see him . Otherwise he 'll think that he ran away from you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: with a shrugAll right . You 'll go back to London at once , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Yes . We hired a car . We left it outside at the gates . We did n't want to see anybody but you , if possible .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Father and mother are out . Aunt Harriet knows — oh , and Tommy and Letty — that Bob was coming to-day ; nobody else . But I can make up something . We 'll keep Tommy and Letty out of it for the moment . Of course , they 'll all have to know in the end .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: We 'll write , of course .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . Tommy and Letty are engaged , by the way .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh !Understanding how he must feel about itOh , Gerald !She makes a movement towards him , but he takes no notice .I 'll send Bob to you ; he 's waiting outside , I expect .TimidlyGood-bye , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: still with his back to herGood-bye , Pamela .

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Wo n't you —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: from the bottom of his heartGo away , go away ! I can n't bear the sound of your voice ; I can n't bear to look at you . Go away !

sp.speaker: PAMELA
sp.p: Oh , Gerald !She goes out .

div.stage: GERALD looks up as she goes out , and then looks quickly down again . When BOB comes in he is still resting with his arm on the mantelpiece looking into the fire .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: looking upHullo .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Hullo .After a pauseIs that all you 've got to say ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 've just seen Pamela .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: trying not to show his eagernessWell ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well — is n't that enough ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: bitterlyDo you want me to fall on , your neck , and say take her and be happy ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: You never loved her .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That 's a lie , and anyhow we wo n't discuss it . She 's going to marry you , and that 's an end of it .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: very eagerlyShe is going to ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: sharplyDo n't you know it ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: mumblingYes , but she might — Ah , you could n't charm her away from me this time .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: with an effortI do n't know what you mean by “ this time . ” I think we 'd better leave Pamela out of it altogether . She 's waiting for you outside . Last time I offered to shake hands with you , you had some fancied grievance against me , and you would n't ; now if there 's any grievance between us , it 's on my side .Holding out his handGood-bye , Bob , and — quite honestly — good luck .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: ignoring the handMagnanimous Gerald !

div.stage: GERALD looks at him in surprise for a moment . Then he shrugs his shoulders , turns round , and goes back to the mantelpiece , and takes a cigarette from the box there .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I 'm tired of you , Bob . If you do n't want me , I do n't want you .He sits down in a chair and lights his cigarette .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: And now I suppose you 're thoroughly pleased with yourself , and quite happy .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: looking at him in absolute wonderHappy ? You fool !Something in BOB 'S face surprises him , and he gets up and saysWhy do you suddenly hate me like this ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: with a bitter laughSuddenly !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: almost frightenedBob !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: letting the jealousy that has been pent up for years come out at lastYou 're surprised ! Surprised ! You would be . You 've never stopped to think what other people are thinking ; you take it for granted that they all love you , and that 's all you care about . Do you think I liked playing second fiddle to you all my life ? Do you think I 've never had any ambitions of my own ? I suppose you thought I was quite happy being one of the crowd of admirers round you , all saying , “ Oh , look at Gerald , is n't he wonderful ? ”

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: astoundedBob , I had no idea — I never dreamt —

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: They thought something of me when I was young . When I first went to school they thought something of me . I daresay even you thought something of me then ; I could come back in the holidays and tell you what school was like , and what a lot they thought of me . They did n't think much of me when you came ; you soon put a stop to that . I was just young Farringdon 's brother then , and when we came home together , all the talk was of the wonderful things Gerald had done . It was like that at Eton ; it was like that at Oxford . It 's always been like that . I managed to get away from you a bit after Oxford , but it went on just the same . “ How do you do , Mr. Farringdon ? Are you any relation to Gerald Farringdon ? ”With the utmost contemptAnd you actually thought I liked that ; you thought I enjoyed it . You thought I smiled modestly and said , “ Oh yes , he 's my brother , my young brother ; is n't he wonderful ? ”

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: hardly able to realise itAnd you 've felt like this for years ?To himselfFor years !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: not noticing himAnd that was n't enough for you . They got you into the Foreign Office — they could have got me there . They could have put me into the ArmyAlmost shoutingAre n't I the eldest son ? But no , it did n't matter about the eldest son — never mind about him ; put him in the City , anywhere as long as he 's out of the way . If we have any influence , we must use it for Gerald — the wonderful Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If this is an indictment , it 's drawn against the wrong person .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: more quietlyThen at last I found a friend ; somebody who took me for my own sake .BitterlyAnd like a damned fool I brought her down here , and she saw you . I might have known what would happen .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Pamela !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Yes , and you took her . After taking everything you could all your life , you took her . She was Bob 's friend — that was quite enough . She must be one more in the crowd of admirers round you . So you took her .TriumphantlyAh , but I got her back in the end . I 've got her now — and I think I 'm square , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , I think you 're square now .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: rather jauntily , as he leans back against the end of the sofa and feels for his cigarette-caseI seem to have surprised you rather .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You 've thought like that about me for years and you 've never said anything ? You 've felt like that about Pamela and you 've never said anything ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: I 've been thinking it over , particularly these last few months — in prison , Gerald . You have a lot of time for thinking in prison . Oh , I know ; you advised me to stand on my head and waggle my legs in the air — something like that . You were full of brilliant ideas . I had a better idea — I thought .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: realising his state of mindMy God , what a time you must have had !

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: furiouslyDamn you ! I wo n't be pitied by you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: coollyAnd you 're not going to be . You 've talked about yourself and thought about yourself quite long enough ; now I 'm going to talk about myself .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: And it wo n't be the first time either .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: quicklyIt will be the first time to you . You say I 've never tried to understand your feelings — have you ever tried to understand mine ? My God , Bob ! I 've thought a good deal more about you than you have about me . Have I ever talked about myself to you ? When a boy does well at school he likes talking about it ; did I ever bore you with it ? Never ! Because I knew how you 'd feel about it . I knew how I 'd feel about it , and so I tried to make it easy for you .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Very noble of you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: angrilyDo n't be such a damned fool , Bob . What 's the good of talking like that ? If whatever I do is wrong , then you 're only convicting yourself ; you 're not convicting me . According to you , if I talk about myself I 'm being conceited and superior , and if I do n't talk about myself , I 'm being noble and still more superior . In fact , whatever I do , I can n't please you . That does n't condemn me ; it condemns yourself .WearilyWhat 's the good of talking ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Go on ; I like to hear it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Very well . We 'll take the definite accusations first . Apart from the general charge of being successful — whatever that amounts to — you accuse me of two things . One you did n't mention just now , but it was more or less obvious the last time I saw you . That was that I neglected to help you when you were in trouble , and that through me you went to prison .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: Yes , I forgot that this time .With an unpleasant laughBut I did n't forget it in prison .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You had a sense of humour once , Bob . I do n't know what 's happened to it lately . Do n't you think it 's rather funny to hate a person steadily for fifteen years , judge all his acts as you 'd hardly judge those of your bitterest enemy , and yet , the first time you are in trouble , to expect him to throw everything on one side and rush to your help — and then to feel bitterly ill-used if he does n't ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: rather taken abackI — you did n't — I did n't —

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: quietlyThat 's been rather like you all through , Bob . You were always the one who had to be helped ; you were always the one who was allowed to have the grievance . Still , that does n't make it any better for me if I could have helped you and did n't . However , I 'm quite certain that I could n't have helped you then . We 'll take the other accusation , that I stole Pamela from you . I 've only got two things to say to that . First , that Pamela was not engaged to you , and was perfectly free to choose between us . Secondly , that you never told me , and I had n't the slightest idea , that you were the least bit fond of her . Indeed , I do n't believe you realized it yourself at that time .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: rather shamefacedI 've realized it since .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , and you 've taken Pamela back since . I think if I were you I would keep her out of it .BOB looks away and GERALD goes onNow we come to the general charge , which seems to bevery deliberatelythat I 'm better than you at games , that I 've got better manners than you , that I 'm cleverer than you — in fact , that I 'm superior to you in every outward way , and am only inferior to you in — well , in the moral qualities .QuietlyBob , what are these moral qualities in which I am so deficient and you so endowed ? You judge me by the qualities I am supposed to have shown to you ; now what have you shown to me ? Have you been generous , have you been friendly , have you been sympathetic ? No ; you 've just told me that for fifteen years you 've hated me and been jealous of me . Things have been rotten for you , I admit ; have you ever tried to make the best of them ? You 've had disadvantages to fight against ; have you ever fought against them ? Never ! You 've turned every trouble into a grievance , and hoarded it up . I said just now I was sick of you . I am — utterly . You said just now you did n't want my pity . You have n't got it ; you 've only got my contempt ....He turns away , and then suddenly turns back , and , holding out his hand to BOB , says utterly unexpectedlyAnd now , damn you ! will you shake hands ?

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: incoherent with surpriseWhat do you — I — you did n't —GERALD 'S hand is still held out , and he is smiling .Oh , Jerry !He takes the hand .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That 's all right . Good-bye , Bob , and good luck .

sp.speaker: BOB
sp.p: bewilderedGood-bye .He tuns round and goes towards the door . Half-way there , he looks over his shoulder and says awkwardlyHad rather a rotten time in prison .GERALD nods . At the door BOB saysPamela and I —

div.stage: With rather a forced smile , GERALD nods again , and BOB goes out .

Left alone , GERALD stands looking into the fire and thinking . He tries sitting down to see if that will make thinking any pleasanter ; then he tries standing up again . He goes to the door in front of the staircase and opens it to see if there is anybody there ; then he goes to the windows at the back and looks through them . Evidently he sees somebody , for he beckons and then returns to his old place by the fire . In a few moments LETTY and TOMMY come in .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: excitedlyI say , has Bob come ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: I could have sworn we saw him just now as we were coming in . At least , Letty swore she did —

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: I know I did .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: So I gave him a shout , but he fairly trekked off . Was it Bob ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . Now look here , I want you to be two nice people . Do n't say anything to anybody . He came , but he did n't want to see the whole crowd of us . He 's going to Canada . I 'll do all the explaining , if you two just say nothing . Do you see ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Of course , Gerald .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: Rather , old boy . Besides , it will make it much better for Letty and me .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: No rival attraction , Tommy means .

div.stage: Enter SIR JAMES and LADY FARRINGDON from the outer hull , having just returned from their lunch .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Ah ! here you all are .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Had a good lunch ?

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Lunch was all right , but the people were dull , very dull .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: There were one or two nice ones , I thought , dear . They all knew about you , Gerald .

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: proudlyOf course they would .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Oh , one or two were all right , but he was — well , I was discussing shorthorns with him after lunch , and he hardly seemed interested at all . Dull , very dull . I 've got no use for that sort of man .

div.stage: During this speech the Butler has come in with a telegram for GERALD .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: taking itJust a moment .He reads it quickly .No answer .Exit Butler .

div.stage: GERALD reads his telegram again more thoughtfully .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: From Pamela , dear ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: From the office . I shall have to go up at once .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: very disappointedOh , Gerald !

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Something on ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Rather an important thing really . I never thought I should get it , but there was just a chance .Looking at his watchOh , I can do it comfortably .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: obviously proud that GERALD is in the thick of thingsWhat is it ? I suppose you must n't tell us .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Something abroad .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: Diplomatic mission , eh ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: That does sound so frightfully exciting .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: proudlyOh , Gerald !ThoughtfullyI wish we had known about it this morning , we could have mentioned it at lunch .

sp.speaker: SIR JAMES
sp.p: That ought to lead to something .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes . I think it will . It 's rather an opportunity :

div.stage: They are all round him now , just as they have always been . The buzz begins .

lg.l: Aha ! you 'll be an ambassador yet . What do you think of that ,
Letty ?

sp.speaker: LETTY
sp.p: Well done , Gerald .

sp.speaker: LADY FARRINGDON
sp.p: How like you , Gerald !

sp.speaker: TOMMY
sp.p: Good old Gerald ! I never knew such a chap . You really are !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: softlyI wish I were n't , Tommy ! Oh , I wish I were n't !

div.stage: They do n't hear him ; they are still buzzing .

docTitle.titlePart: THE BOY COMES HOME A COMEDY IN ONE ACT

castItem.role: This play was first produced by Mr. Owen Nares at the Victoria Palace

castItem.roleDesc: 1918 , with the following cast

stage.stage: [ SCENE .— A room in UNCLE JAMES 'S house in the Cromwell Road . ]
[ TIME .— The day after the War . ]

body.stage: Any room in UNCLE JAMES 'S house is furnished in heavy mid-Victorian style ; this particular morning-room is perhaps solider and more respectable even than the others , from the heavy table in the middle of it to the heavy engravings on the walls . There are two doors to it . The one at the back opens into the hall , the one at the side into the dining-room .

PHILIP comes from the hall and goes into the dining-room . Apparently he finds nothing there , for he returns to the morning-room , looks about him for a moment and then rings the bell . It is ten o'clock , and he wants his breakfast . He picks up the paper , and sits in a heavy armchair in front of the fire — a pleasant-looking well-built person of twenty-three , with an air of decisiveness about him . MARY , the parlour-maid , comes in .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Did you ring , Master Philip ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: absentlyYes ; I want some breakfast , please , Mary .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: coldlyBreakfast has been cleared away an hour ago .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Exactly . That 's why I rang . You can boil me a couple of eggs or something . And coffee , not tea .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I 'm sure I do n't know what Mrs. Higgins will say ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: getting upWho is Mrs. Higgins ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: The cook . And she 's not used to being put about like this .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Do you think she 'll say something ?

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: I do n't know what she 'll say .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: You need n't tell me , you know , if you do n't want to . Anyway , I do n't suppose it will shock me . One gets used to it in the Army .He smiles pleasantly at her .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Well , I 'll do what I can , sir . But breakfast at eight sharp is the master 's rule , just as it used to be before you went away to the war .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Before I went away to the war I did a lot of silly things . Do n't drag them up now .More curtlyTwo eggs , and if there 's a ham bring that along too .He turns away .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: doubtfully , as she prepares to goWell , I 'm sure I do n't know what Mrs. Higgins will say .Exit MARY .

body.stage: As she goes out she makes way for AUNT EMILY to come in , a kind-hearted mid-Victorian lady who has never had any desire for the vote .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: There you are , Philip ! Good-morning , dear . Did you sleep well ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rather ; splendidly , thanks , Aunt Emily . How are you ?He kisses her .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: And did you have a good breakfast ? Naughty boy to be late for it . I always thought they had to get up so early in the Army .

lg.l: They do . That 's why they 're so late when they get out of the
Army .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Dear me ! I should have thought a habit of four years would have stayed with you .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Every morning for four years , as I 've shot out of bed , I 've said to myself , “ Wait ! A time will come . ”SmilingThat does n't really give a habit a chance .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Well , I daresay you wanted your sleep out . I was so afraid that a really cosy bed would keep you awake after all those years in the trenches .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , one is n't in the trenches all the time . And one gets leave — if one 's an officer .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: reproachfullyYou did n't spend much of it with us , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: taking her handsI know ; but you did understand , did n't you , dear ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: We 're not very gay , and I know you must have wanted gaiety for the little time you had . But I think your Uncle James felt it . After all , dear , you 've lived with us for some years , and he is your guardian .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I know . You 've been a darling to me always , Aunt Emily . ButawkwardlyUncle James and I —

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Of course , he is a little difficult to get on with . I 'm more used to him . But I 'm sure he really is very fond of you , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
