sp.p: H 'm ! I always used to be frightened of him .... I suppose he 's just the same . He seemed just the same last night — and he still has breakfast at eight o'clock . Been making pots of money , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: He never tells me exactly , but he did speak once about the absurdity of the excess-profits tax . You see , jam is a thing the Army wants .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It certainly gets it .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: It was so nice for him , because it made him feel he was doing his bit , helping the poor men in the trenches .

body.stage: Enter MARY .

sp.speaker: MARY
sp.p: Mrs. Higgins wishes to speak to you , ma'am .She looks at PHILIP as much as to say , “ There you are ! ”

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: getting upYes , I 'll come .To PHILIPI think I 'd better just see what she wants , Philip .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: firmly to MARYTell Mrs. Higgins to come here .MARY hesitates and looks at her mistress .At once , please .Exit MARY .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: upsetPhilip , dear , I do n't know what Mrs. Higgins will say —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No ; nobody seems to . I thought we might really find out for once .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: going towards the doorPerhaps I 'd better go —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: putting his arm round her waistOh no , you must n't . You see , she really wants to see me .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: You ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes ; I ordered breakfast five minutes ago .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Philip ! My poor boy ! Why did n't you tell me ? and I daresay I could have got it for you . Though I do n't know what Mrs. Higgins —

body.stage: An extremely angry voice is heard outside , and MRS. HIGGINS , stout and aggressive , comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINStruculentlyYou sent for me , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: nervouslyYes — er — I think if you — perhaps —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: calmlyI sent for you , Mrs. Higgins . I want some breakfast . Did n't Mary tell you ?

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINS . Breakfast is at eight o'clock . It always has been as long as I 've been in this house , and always will be until I get further orders .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , you 've just got further orders . Two eggs , and if there 's a ham —

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINS . Orders . We 're talking about orders . From whom in this house do I take orders , may I ask ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: In this case from me .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINSplaying her trump-cardIn that case , ma'am , I wish to give a month 's notice from to-day . Inclusive .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: quickly , before his aunt can say anythingCertainly . In fact , you 'd probably prefer it if my aunt gave you notice , and then you could go at once . We can easily arrange that .TO AUNT EMILY as he takes out a fountain pen and cheque-bookWhat do you pay her ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: faintlyForty-five pounds .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: writing on his kneeTwelves into forty-five ....Pleasantly to MRS. HIGGINS , but without looking upI hope you do n't mind a Cox 's cheque . Some people do ; but this is quite a good one .Tearing it outHere you are .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINStaken abackWhat 's this ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Your wages instead of notice . Now you can go at once .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINS . Who said anything about going ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: surprisedI 'm sorry ; I thought you did .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINS . If it 's only a bit of breakfast , I do n't say but what I might n't get it , if I 'm asked decent .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: putting back the chequeThen let me say again , “ Two eggs , ham and coffee . ” And Mary can bring the ham up at once , and I 'll get going on that .Turning awayThanks very much .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: HIGGINS . Well , I — well — well !Exit speechless .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: surprisedIs that all she ever says ? It is n't much to worry about .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Philip , how could you ! I should have been terrified .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , you see , I 've done your job for two years out there .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: What job ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Mess President .... I think I 'll go and see about that ham .

body.stage: He smiles at her and goes out into the dining-room . AUNT EMILY wanders round the room , putting a few things tidy as is her habit , when she is interrupted by the entrance of UNCLE JAMES . JAMES is not a big man , nor an impressive one in his black morning-coat ; and his thin straggly beard , now going grey , does not hide a chin of any great power ; but he has a severity which passes for strength with the weak .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Philip down yet ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: He 's just having his breakfast .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: looking at his watchTen o'clock .Snapping it shut and putting it backTen o'clock . I say ten o'clock , Emily .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Yes , dear , I heard you .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You do n't say anything ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: vaguelyI expect he 's tired after that long war .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That 's no excuse for not being punctual . I suppose he learnt punctuality in the Army ?

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: I expect he learnt it , James , but I understood him to say that he 'd forgotten it .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Then the sooner he learns it again the better . I particularly stayed away from the office to-day in order to talk things over with him , andlooking cat his watchhere 's ten o'clock — past ten — and no sign of him . I 'm practically throwing away a day .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: What are you going to talk to him about ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: His future , naturally . I have decided that the best thing he can do is to come into the business at once .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Are you really going to talk it over with him , James , or are you just going to tell him that he must come ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: surprisedWhat do you mean ? What 's the difference ? Naturally we shall talk it over first , and — er — naturally he 'll fall in with my wishes .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: I suppose he can hardly help himself , poor boy .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Not until he 's twenty-five , anyhow . When he 's twenty-five he can have his own money and do what he likes with it .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: timidlyBut I think you ought to consult him at little , dear . After all , he has been fighting for us .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: with his back to the fireNow that 's the sort of silly sentiment that there 's been much too much of . I object to it strongly . I do n't want to boast , but I think I may claim to have done my share . I gave up my nephew to my country , and I — er — suffered from the shortage of potatoes to an extent that you probably did n't realize . Indeed , if it had n't been for your fortunate discovery about that time that you did n't really like potatoes , I do n't know how we should have carried on . And , as I think I 've told you before , the excess-profits tax seemed to me a singularly stupid piece of legislation — but I paid it . And I do n't go boasting about how much I paid .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: unconvincedWell , I think that Philip 's four years out there have made him more of a man ; he does n't seem somehow like a boy who can be told what to do . I 'm sure they 've taught him something .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I 've no doubt that they 've taught him something about — er — bombs and — er — which end a revolver goes off , and how to form fours . But I do n't see that that sort of thing helps him to decide upon the most suitable career for a young man in after-war conditions .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Well , I can only say you 'll find him different .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I did n't notice any particular difference last night .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: I think you 'll find him rather more — I can n't quite think of the word , but Mrs. Higgins could tell you what I mean .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Of course , if he likes to earn his living any other way , he may ; but I don t see how he proposes to do it so long as I hold the purse-strings .Looking at his watchPerhaps you 'd better tell him that I cannot wait any longer .

body.stage: EMILY opens the door leading into the dining-room and talks through it to PHILIP .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: Philip , your uncle is waiting to see you before he goes to the office . Will you be long , dear ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: from the dining-roomIs he in a hurry ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: shortlyYes .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: He says he is rather , dear .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Could n't he come and talk in here ? It would n't interfere with my breakfast .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: He says he 'd rather you came to him , darling .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: resignedOh , well .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: to JAMESHe 'll be here directly , dear . Just sit down in front of the fire and make yourself comfortable with the paper . He wo n't keep you long .She arranges him .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: taking the paperThe morning is not the time to make oneself comfortable . It 's a most dangerous habit . I nearly found myself dropping off in front of the fire just now . I do n't like this hanging about , wasting the day .He opens the paper .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: You should have had a nice sleep , dear , while you could . We were up so late last night listening to Philip 's stories .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , yes .He begins a yawn and stifles it hurriedly .You must n't neglect your duties , Emily . I 've no doubt you have plenty to do .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: All right , James , then I 'll leave you . But do n't be hard on the boy .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: sleepilyI shall be just , Emily ; you can rely upon that .

sp.speaker: EMILY
sp.p: going to the doorI do n't think that 's quite what I meant .She goes out .

body.stage: JAMES , who is now quite comfortable , begins to nod . He wakes up with a start , turns over the paper , and nods again . Soon he is breathing deeply with closed eyes .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: coming inSorry to have kept you waiting , but I was a bit late for breakfast .He takes out his pipe .Are we going to talk business or what ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: taking out his matchA bit late ! I make it just two hours .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: pleasantlyAll right , Uncle James . Call it two hours late . Or twenty-two hours early for tomorrow 's breakfast , if you like .He sits down in a chair on the opposite side of the table from his uncle , and lights his pipe .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You smoke now ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: staggeredI what ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: nodding at his pipeYou smoke ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Good heavens ! what did yolk think we did in France ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Before you start smoking all over the house , I should have thought you would have asked your aunt 's permission .

body.stage: PHILIP looks at him in amazement , and then goes to the door .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: callingAunt Emily !... Aunt Emily !... Do you mind my smoking in here ?

sp.speaker: AUNT EMILY
sp.p: from upstairsOf course not , darling .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: to JAMES , as he returns to his chairOf course not , darling .He puts back his pipe in his mouth .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Now , understand once and for all , Philip , while you remain in my house I expect not only punctuality , but also civility and respect . I will not have impertinence .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: unimpressedWell , that 's what I want to talk to you about , Uncle James . About staying in your house , I mean .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't know what you do mean .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , we do n't get on too well together , and I thought perhaps I 'd better take rooms somewhere . You could give me an allowance until I came into my money . Or I suppose you could give me the money now if you really liked . I do n't quite know how father left it to me .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: coldlyYou come into your money when you are twenty-five . Your father very wisely felt that to trust a large sum to a mere boy of twenty-one was simply putting temptation in his way . Whether I have the power or not to alter his dispositions , I certainly do n't propose to do so .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: If it comes to that , I am twenty-five .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Indeed ? I had an impression that that event took place in about two years ’ time . When did you become twenty-five , may I ask ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: quietlyIt was on the Somme . We were attacking the next day and my company was in support . We were in a so-called trench on the edge of a wood — a damned rotten place to be , and we got hell . The company commander sent back to ask if we could move . The C. O . said , “ Certainly not ; hang on . ” We hung on ; doing nothing , you know — just hanging on and waiting for the next day . Of course , the Boche knew all about that . He had it on us nicely ....SadlyDear old Billy ! he was one of the best — our company commander , you know . They got him , poor devil ! That left me in command of the company . I sent a runner back to ask if I could move . Well , I 'd had a bit of a scout on my own and found a sort of trench five hundred yards to the right . Not what you 'd call a trench , of course , but compared to that wood — well , it was absolutely Hyde Park . I described the position and asked if I could go there . My man never came back . I waited an hour and sent another man . He went west too . Well , I was n't going to send a third . It was murder . So I had to decide . We 'd lost about half the company by this time , you see . Well , there were three things I could do — hang on , move to this other trench , against orders , or go back myself and explain the situation .... I moved .... And then I went back to the C. O . and told him I 'd moved .... And then I went back to the company again ....QuietlyThat was when I became twenty-five .... or thirty-five .... or forty-five .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: recovering himself with an effortAh yes , yes .He coughs awkwardly .No doubt points like that frequently crop up in the trenches . I am glad that you did well out there , and I 'm sure your Colonel would speak kindly of you ; but when it comes to choosing a career for you now that you have left the Army , my advice is not altogether to be despised . Your father evidently thought so , or he would not have entrusted you to my care .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: My father did n't foresee this war .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Yes , yes , but you make too much of this war . All you young boys seem to think you 've come back from France to teach us our business . You 'll find that it is you who 'll have to learn , not we .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'm quite prepared to learn ; in fact , I want to .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Excellent . Then we can consider that settled .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , we have n't settled yet what business I 'm going to learn .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't think that 's very difficult . I propose to take you into my business . You 'll start at the bottom of course , but it will be a splendid opening for you .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: thoughtfullyI see . So you 've decided it for me ? The jam business .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: sharplyIs there anything to be ashamed of in that ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh no , nothing at all . Only it does n't happen to appeal to me .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: If you knew which side your bread was buttered , it would appeal to you very considerably .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I 'm afraid I can n't see the butter for the jam .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I do n't want any silly jokes of that sort . You were glad enough to get it out there , I 've no doubt .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh yes . Perhaps that 's why I 'm so sick of it now .... No , it 's no good , Uncle James ; you must think of something else .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: with a sneerPerhaps you 've thought of something else ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , I had some idea of being an architect —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You propose to start learning to be an architect at twenty-three ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: smilingWell , I could n't start before , could I ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Exactly . And now you 'll find it 's too late .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Is it ? Are n't there going to be any more architects , or doctors , or solicitors , or barristers ? Because we 've all lost four years of our lives , are all the professions going to die out ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: And how old do you suppose you 'll be before you 're earning money as an architect ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The usual time , whatever that may be . If I 'm four years behind , so is everybody else .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , I think it 's high time you began to earn a living at once .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Look here , Uncle James , do you really think that you can treat me like a boy who 's just left school ? Do you think four years at the front have made no difference at all ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: If there had been any difference , I should have expected it to take the form of an increased readiness in obey orders and recognize authority .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: regretfullyYou are evidently determined to have a row . Perhaps I had better tell you once and for all that I refuse to go into the turnip and vegetable narrow business .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: thumping the table angrilyAnd perhaps I 'd better tell you , sir , once and for all , that I do n't propose to allow rude rudeness from an impertinent young puppy .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: reminiscentlyI remember annoying our Brigadier once . He was covered with red , had a very red face , about twenty medals , and a cold blue eye . He told me how angry he was for about five minutes while I stood to attention . I 'm afraid you are n't nearly impressive , Uncle James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: rather upsetOh !Recovering himselfFortunately I have other means of impressing you . The power of the purse goes a long way in this world . I propose to use it .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I see .... Yes ... that 's rather awkward , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: pleasantlyI think you 'll find it very awkward .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: thoughtfullyYes .

body.stage: With an amused laugh JAMES settles down to his paper as if the interview were over .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: to himselfI suppose I shall have to think of another argument .He takes out a revolver from him pocket and fondles it affectionately .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: looking up suddenly as he is doing this — amazedWhat on earth are you doing ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Souvenir from France . Do you know , Uncle . James , that this revolver has killed about twenty Germans ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: shortlyOh ! Well , do n't go playing about with it here , or you 'll be killing Englishmen before you know where you are .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , you never know .He raises it leisurely and points it at his uncle .It 's a nice little weapon .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: angrilyPut it down , sir . You ought to have grown out of monkey tricks like that in the Army . You ought to know better than to point an unloaded revolver at anybody . That 's the way accidents always happen .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Not when you 've been on a revolver course and know all about it . Besides , it is loaded .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: very angry because he is frightened suddenlyPut it down at once , sir .PHILIP turns it away from him and examines it carelessly .What 's the matter with you ? Have you gone mad suddenly ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: mildlyI thought you 'd be interested in it . It 's shot such a lot of Germans .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , it wo n't want to shoot any more , and the sooner you get rid of it the better .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: I wonder . Does it ever occur to you , Uncle James , that there are about a hundred thousand people in England who own revolvers , who are quite accustomed to them and — who have nobody to practise on now ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No , sir , it certainly does n't .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: thoughtfullyI wonder if it will make any difference . You know , one gets so used to potting at people . It 's rather difficult to realize suddenly that one ought n't to .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: getting upI do n't know what the object of this tomfoolery is , if it has one . But you understand that I expect you to come to the office with me to-morrow at nine o'clock . Kindly see that you 're punctual .He turns to go away .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: softlyUncle James .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: over his shoulderI have no more —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: in his parade voiceDamn it , sir ! stand to attention when you talk to an officer !JAMES instinctively turns round and stiffens himself .That 's better ; you can sit down if you like .He motions JAMES to his chair with the revolver .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: going nervously to his chairWhat does this bluff mean ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It is n't bluff , it 's quite serious .Pointing the revolver at his uncleDo sit down .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: sitting donorThreats , eh ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Persuasion .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: At the point of the revolver ? You settle your arguments by force ? Good heavens , sir ! this is just the very thing that we were fighting to put down .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: We were fighting ! We ! We ! Uncle , you 're humorist .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: , Well , “ you , ” if you prefer it . Although those of us who stayed at home —

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , never mind about the excess profits now . I can tell you quite well what we fought for . We used force to put down force . That 's what I 'm doing now . You were going to use force — the force of money — to make me do what you wanted . Now I 'm using force to stop it .He levels the revolver again .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You 're — you 're going to shoot your old uncle ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Why not ? I 've shot lots of old uncles — Landsturmers .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: But those were Germans ! It 's different shooting Germans . You 're in England now . You could n't have a crime on your conscience like that .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Ah , but you must n't think that after four years of war one has quite the same ideas about the sanctity of human life . How could one ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You 'll find that juries have kept pretty much the same ideas , I fancy .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Yes , but revolvers often go off accidentally . You said so yourself . This is going to be the purest accident . Ca n't you see it in the papers ? “ The deceased 's nephew , who was obviously upset — ”

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I suppose you think it 's brave to come back from the front and threaten a defenceless man with a revolver ? Is that the sort of fair play they teach you in the Army ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Good heavens ! of course it is . You do n't think that you wait until the other side has got just as many guns as you before you attack ? You 're really rather lucky . Strictly speaking , I ought to have thrown half a dozen bombs at you first .Taking one out of his pocketAs it happens , I 've only got one .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: thoroughly alarmedPut that back at once .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: putting down the revolver and taking it in his handsYou hold it in the right hand — so — taking care to keep the lever down . Then you take the pin in the finger — so , and — but perhaps this does n't interest you ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: edging his chair awayPut it down at once , sir . Good heavens ! anything might happen .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: putting it down and taking up the revolver againDoes it ever occur to you , Uncle James , that there are about three million people in England who know all about bombs , and how to throw them , and —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: It certainly does not occur to me . I should never dream of letting these things occur to me .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: looking at the bomb regretfullyIt 's rather against my principles as a soldier , but just to make things a bit more fair —generouslyyou shall have it .He holds it out to him suddenly .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: shrinking back againCertainly not , sir . It might go off at any moment .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: putting it back in his pocketOh no ; it 's quite useless ; there 's no detonator ....SternlyNow , then , let 's talk business .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: What do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Strictly speaking , you should be holding your hands over your head and saying “ Kamerad ! ” However , I 'll let you off that . All I ask from you is that you should be reasonable .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: And if I refuse , you 'll shoot me ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Well , I do n't quite know , Uncle James . I expect we should go through this little scene again to-morrow . You have n't enjoyed it , have you ? Well , there 's lots more of it to come . We 'll rehearse it every day . One day , if you go on being unreasonable , the thing will go off . Of course , you think that I should n't have the pluck to fire . But you can n't be quite certain . It 's a hundred to one that I sha n't — only I might . Fear — it 's a horrible thing . Elderly men die of it sometimes .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Pooh ! I 'm not to be bluffed like that .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: suddenlyYou 're quite right ; you 're not that sort . I made a mistake .Aiming carefullyI shall have to do it straight off , after all . One — two —

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: on his knees , with uplifted hands , in an agony of terrorPhilip ! Mercy ! What are your terms ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: picking him up by the scruff , and helping him into the chairGood man , that 's the way to talk . I 'll get them for you . Make yourself comfortable in front of the fire till I come back . Here 's the paper .He gives his uncle the paper , and goes out into the hall .

body.stage: JAMES opens his eyes with a start and looks round him in a bewildered way . He rubs his heart , takes out his match and looks at it , and then stares round the room again . The door from the dining-room opens , and PHILIP comes in with a piece of toast in his hand .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: his mouth fullYou wanted to see me , Uncle James ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: still bewilderedThat 's all right , my boy , that 's all right . What have you been doing ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: surprisedBreakfast .Putting the last piece in his mouthRather late , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: That 's all right .He laughs awkwardly .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Anything the matter ? You do n't look your usual bright self .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I — er — seem to have dropped asleep in front of the fire . Most unusual thing for me to have done . Most unusual .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Let that be a lesson to you not to get up so early . Of course , if you 're in the Army you can n't help yourself . Thank Heaven I 'm out of it , and my own master again .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Ah , that 's what I wanted to talk to you about . Sit down , Philip .He indicates the chair by the fire .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: taking a chair by the tableYou have that , uncle ; I shall be all right here .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: hastilyNo , no ; you come here .He gives PHILIP the armchair and sits by the table himself .I should be dropping off again .He laughs awkwardly .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Righto .He puts his hand to his pocket . UNCLE JAMES shivers and looks at him to horror . PHILIP brings out his pipe , and a sickly grin of relief comes into JAMES 'S face .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: I suppose you smoked a lot in France ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Rather ! Nothing else to do . It 's allowed in here ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: hastilyYes , yes , of course .PHILIP lights his pipe .Well now , Philip , what are you going to do , now you 've left the Army ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: promptlyBurn my uniform and sell my revolver .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: starting at the word “ revolver ”Sell your revolver , eh ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: surprisedWell , I do n't want it now , do I ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: No .... Oh no .... Oh , most certainly not , I should say . Oh , I can n't see why you should want it at all .With an uneasy laughYou 're in England now . No need for revolvers here — eh ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: staring at himWell , no , I hope not .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: hastilyQuite so . Well now , Philip , what next ? We must find a profession for you .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: yawningI suppose so . I have n't really thought about it much .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: You never wanted to be an architect ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: surprisedArchitect ?JAMES rubs his head and wonders what made him think of architect .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Or anything like that .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: It 's a bit late , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Well , if you 're four years behind , so is everybody else .He feels vaguely that he has heard this argument before .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: smilingTo tell the truth , I do n't feel I mind much anyway . Anything you like — except a commissionaire . I absolutely refuse to wear uniform again .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: How would you like to come into the business ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: The jam business ? Well , I do n't know . You would n't want me to salute you in the mornings ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: My dear boy , no !

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: All right , I 'll try it if you like . I do n't know if I shall be any good — what do you do ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: It 's your experience in managing and — er — handling men which I hope will be of value .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Oh , I can do that all right .Stretching himself luxuriouslyUncle James , do you realize that I 'm never going to salute again , or wear a uniform , or get wet — really wet , I mean — or examine men 's feet , or stand to attention when I 'm spoken to , or — oh , lots more things . And best of all , I 'm never going to be frightened again . Have you ever known what it is to be afraid — really afraid ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: embarrassedI — er — well —He coughs .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: No , you could n't — not really afraid of death , I mean . Well , that 's over now . Good lord ! I could spend the rest of my life in the British Museum and be happy ....

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: getting upAll right , we 'll try you in the office . I expect you want a holiday first , though .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: getting upMy dear uncle , this is holiday . Being in London is holiday . Buying an evening paper — wearing a waistcoat again — running after a bus — anything — it 's all holiday .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: All right , then , come along with me now , and I 'll introduce you to Mr. Bamford .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Right . Who 's he ?

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: Our manager . A little stiff , but a very good fellow . He 'll be delighted to hear that you are coming into the firm .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: smilingPerhaps I 'd better bring my revolver , in case he is n't .

sp.speaker: JAMES
sp.p: laughing with forced heartiness as they go together to the doorHa , ha ! A good joke that ! Ha , ha , ha ! A good joke — but only a joke , of course . Ha , ha ! He , he , he !

body.stage: PHILIP goes out . JAMES , following him , turns at the door , and looks round the room in a bewildered way . Was it a dream , or was n't it ? He will never be quite certain .

docTitle.titlePart: BELINDA An April Folly in Three Acts

castItem.roleDesc: her daughter

set.p: The action takes place in Belinda 's country-house in Devonshire at the end of April .

titlePage.docImprint: This play was first produced by Mr. Dion Boucicault at the New Theatre ,London, on April 8 ,1918, with the following cast : Belinda Tremayne — IRENE VANBRUGH . Delia — ISOBEL ELSOM . Harold Baxter — DION BOUCICAULT . Claude Devenish — DENNIS NEILSON-TERRY . John Tremayne — BEN WEBSTER . Betty — ANNE WALDEN .

div.head: ACT I
div.stage: It is a lovely April afternoon — a foretaste of summer — in BELINDA 'S garden .

BETTY , a middle-aged servant , is fastening a hammock — its first appearance this year — between two trees at the back . In front of these there is a solid oak garden-table , with a comfortable chair on the right of it and a straight-backed one on the left . There are books , papers , and magazines on the table . BELINDA , of whom we shall know more presently , is on the other side of the open windows which look on to the garden , talking to BETTY .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: from inside the houseAre you sure you 're tying it up tightly enough , Betty ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: coming to front of hammockYes , ma'am ; I think it 's firm .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Because I 'm not the fairy I used to be .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: trying the knots at the other end of the hammockYes , ma'am ; it 's quite firm this end too .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: It 's not the ends I 'm frightened of ; it 's the middle where the weight 's coming .She comes into the garden .It looks very nice .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: trying the middle of it with her handI asked them at the Stores if they were quite sure it would bear me , and they said it would take anything up to — I forget how many tons . I know I thought it was rather rude of them .Looking at it anxiouslyHow does one get in ? So trying to be a sailor !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I think you sit in it , ma'am , and thenexplaining with her handsthrow your legs over .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I see .She sits gingerly in the hammock , and then , with a sudden flutter of white , does what BETTY suggests .Yes .Regretfully .I 'm afraid that was rather wasted on you , Betty . We must have some spectators next time .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Cushions .She arranges them at her back with BETTY 'S help . With a sigh of comfortThere ! Now then , Betty , about callers .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: If Mr. Baxter calls — he is the rather prim gentleman —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am ; the one who 's been here several times before .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: giving BETTY a quick lookYes . Well , if he calls , you 'll say , “ Not at home . ”

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: He will say , “ Oh — er — oh — er — really . ” Then you 'll smile very sweetly and say , “ I beg your pardon , was it Mr. Baxter ? ” And he 'll say , “ Yes ! ” and you 'll say , “ Oh , I beg your pardon , sir ; this way , please . ”

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: That 's right , Betty . Well now , if Mr. Devenish calls — he is the rather poetical gentleman —

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am ; the one who 's always coming here .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a pleased smileYes . Well , if he calls you 'll say , “ Not at home . ”

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: He 'll immediately throw down his bunch of flowers and dive despairingly into the moat . You 'll stop him , just as he is going in , and say , “ I beg your pardon , sir , was it Mr. Devenish ? ” And he will say , “ Yes ! ” and you will say , “ Oh , I beg your pardon , sir ; this way , please . ”

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am . And suppose they both call together ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: We wo n't suppose anything so exciting , Betty .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: No , ma'am . And suppose any other gentleman calls ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a sighThere are n't any other gentlemen .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: It might be a clergyman , come to ask for a subscription like .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: If it 's a clergyman , Betty , I shall — I shall want your assistance out of the hammock first .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: That 's all . To anybody else I 'm not at home .Trying to secure book on table and nearly falling out of the hammock .Oh , just give me that little green book .Pointing to books on the table .The one at the bottom there — that 's the one .BETTY gives it to her .Thank you .Reading the title .“ The Lute of Love , ” by Claude Devenish .To herself as she turns the pages .It does n't seem much for half-a-crown when you think of the Daily Telegraph . ... Lute ... Lute .... I should have quite a pretty mouth if I kept on saying that .With a great deal of expression .Lute !She pats her mouth back .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Is that all , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: That 's all .BETTY prepares to go .Oh , what am I thinking of !Waving to the table .I want that review ; I think it 's the blue one .As BETTY begins to look .It has an article by Mr. Baxter on the “ Rise of Lunacy in the Eastern Counties ” — yes , that 's the one . I 'd better have that too ; I 'm just at the most exciting place . You shall have it after me , Betty .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Is that all , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , that really is all .

div.stage: BETTY goes into the house .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reading to herself“ It is a matter of grave concern to all serious students of social problems — ”Putting the review down in hammock and shaking her head gently .But not in April .Lazily opening the book and reading .“ Tell me where is love ” — well , that 's the question , is n't it ?She puts the book down , gives a sigh of happiness , and lazily closes her eyes . DELIA comes into the garden , from Paris . She is decidedly a modern girl , pretty and self-possessed . Her hair is half-way up ; waiting for her birthday , perhaps . She sees her mother suddenly , stops , and then goes on tiptoe to the head of the hammock . She smiles and kisses her mother on the forehead . BELINDA , looking supremely unconscious , goes on sleeping . DELIA kisses her lightly again . BELINDA wakes up with an extraordinarily natural start , and is just about to say , “ Oh , Mr. Devenish — you must n't ! ” — when she sees DELIA .Delia !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Well , mummy , are n't you glad to see me ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: My darling child !They kiss each other frantically .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Say you 're glad .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sitting upMy darling , I 'm absolutely — Hold the hammock while I get out , dear ; we do n't want an accident .Getting out with DELIA 'S helpThey 're all right when you 're there , and they 'll bear two tons , but they 're horrid getting in and out of .Kissing her againDarling , it really is you ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , it is jolly seeing you again . I believe you were asleep .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with dignityCertainly not , child . I was reading “ The Nineteenth Century ” —with an air— and after .EarnestlyDarling , was n't it next Thursday you were coming back ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: No , this Thursday , silly .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: penitentlyOh , my darling , and I was going over to Paris to bring you home .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I half expected you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: So confusing their both being called Thursday . And you were leaving school for the very last time . If you do n't forgive me , Delia , I shall cry .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: stroking her hand fondlySilly mother !

div.stage: BELINDA sits down in a basket chair and DELIA sits on a table next to her .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Is n't it a lovely day for April , darling ! I 've wanted to say that to somebody all day , and you 're the first person who 's given me the chance . Oh , I said it to Betty , but she only said , “ Yes , ma'am . ”

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Poor mother !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: jumping up suddenly and kissing DELIA againI simply must have another one . And to think that you 're never going back to school any more .Looking at her fondlyDarling , you are looking pretty .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Am I ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Lovely .Going back to her seatAnd now you 're going to stay with me for just as long as you want a mother .AnxiouslyDarling , you did n't mind being sent away to school , did you ? It is the usual thing , you know .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Silly mother ! of course it is .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: relievedI 'm so glad you think so too .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Have you been very lonely without me ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: holding up a fingerThe truth , mummy !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I 've missed you horribly , Delia .Primly .The absence of female companionship of the requisite —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Are you really all alone ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: smiling mysteriouslyWell , not always , of course .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: excitedly , at she slips off the tableMummy , I believe you 're being bad again .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Really , darling , you forget that I 'm old enough to be — in fact , am — your mother .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: nodding her headYou are being bad .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: rising with dignity and drawing herself up to her full heightMy child , that is not the way to — Oh , I say , what a lot taller I am than you !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And prettier .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: fluttering her eyelidsOh , do you think so ?FirmlyDo n't be silly , child .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: holding up a fingerNow tell me all that 's been happening here at once .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a sighAnd I was just going to ask you how you were getting on with your French .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Bother French ! You 've been having a much more interesting time than I have , so you 've got to tell .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a happy sighO-oh !She sinks back into her chair .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Is it like the Count at Scarborough ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: surprised and painedMy darling , what do you mean ?

lg.l: Do n't you remember the Count who kept proposing to you at
Scarborough ? I do .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reproachfullyDear one , you were the merest child , paddling about on the beach and digging castles .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: smiling to herselfI was old enough to notice the Count .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sadlyAnd I 'd bought her a perfectly new spade ! How one deceives oneself !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And then there was the M. P . who proposed at Windermere .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , dear , but it was n't seconded — I mean he never got very far with it .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And the artist in Wales .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Darling child , what a memory you have . No wonder your teachers are pleased with you .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: settling herself comfortablyNow tell me all about this one .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: meeklyWhich one ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: excitedlyOh , are there lots ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: severelyOnly two .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Two ! You abandoned woman !

lg.l: It 's something in the air , darling . I 've never been in
Devonshire in April before .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Is it really serious this time ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: painedI wish you would n't say this time , Delia . It sounds so unromantic . If you 'd only put it into French — cette fois — it sounds so much better . Cette fois .Parentally .When one 's daughter has just returned from an expensive schooling in Paris , one likes to feel —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What I meant , dear , was , am I to have a stepfather at last ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Now you 're being too French , darling .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Why , do you still think father may be alive ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Why not ? It 's only eighteen years since he left us , and he was quite a young man then .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Yes , but surely you 'd have heard from him in all those years , if he 'd been alive ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , he has n't heard from me , and I 'm still alive .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: looking earnestly at her motherI shall never understand it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Understand what ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Were you as heavenly when you were young as you are now ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: rapturouslyOh , I was sweet !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And yet he left you after only six months .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: rather crosslyI wish you would n't keep on saying he left me . I left him too .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: smiling to herselfWell , you see , he was quite certain he knew how to manage women , and I was quite certain I knew how to manage men .Thoughtfully .If only one of us had been certain , it would have been all right .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: seriouslyWhat really happened , mummy ? I 'm grown up now , so I think you ought to tell me .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: thoughtfullyThat was about all , you know ... except for his beard .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Had he a beard ? How funny !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , dear , it was ; but he never would see it . He took it quite seriously .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And did you say dramatically , “ If you really loved me , you 'd take it off ” ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: apologeticallyI 'm afraid I did , darling .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And what did he say ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: He said — very rudely — that , if I loved him , I 'd do my hair in a different way .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How ridiculous !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: touching her hairOf course , I did n't do it like this then .With a sigh .I suppose we never ought to have married , really .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Why did you ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Mother rather wanted it .Solemnly .Delia , never get married because your mother — Oh , I forgot ; I 'm your mother .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: And I do n't want a better one .... And so you left each other ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But , darling , did n't you tell him there was going to be a Me ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh no !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I wonder why not ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , you see , if I had , he might have wanted to stay .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: hurtIf he did n't want to stay for me , I did n't want him to stay for you .Penitently .Forgive me , darling , but I did n't know you very well then .DELIA jumps off the table and hugs her mother impetuously .We 've been very happy together , have n't we ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: going back to her seatI should think we have .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I do n't want to deny you anything , and , of course , if you 'd like a stepfatherlooking down modestlyor two —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , you have been enjoying yourself .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Only you see how awkward it would be if Jack turned up in the middle of the wedding , like — like Eugene Aram .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Enoch Arden , darling .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: It 's very confusing their having the same initials . Perhaps I 'd better call them both E. A. in future and then I shall be safe . Well , anyhow it would be awkward , darling , would n't it ? Not that I should know him from Adam after all these years — except for a mole on his left arm .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Perhaps Adam had a mole .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No , darling ; you 're thinking of Noah . He had two .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: thoughtfullyI wonder what would happen if you met somebody whom you really did fall in love with ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reproachfullyNow you 're being serious , and it 's April .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Are n't these two — the present two — serious ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh no ! They think they are , but they are n't a bit , really . Besides , I 'm doing them such a lot of good . I 'm sure they 'd hate to marry me , but they love to think they 're in love with me , and — I love it , and — and they love it , and — and we all love it .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You really are the biggest , darlingest baby who ever lived .Kisses her .Do say I sha n't spoil your lovely times .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: surprisedSpoil them ? Why , you 'll make them more lovely than ever .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Well , but do they know you have a grown-up daughter ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: suddenly realizingOh !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: It does n't really matter , because you do n't look a day more than thirty .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: absentlyNo .Hurriedly .I mean , how sweet of you — only —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: playing with her ringsWell , one of them , Mr. Baxter — Harold —she looks quickly up at DELIA and down again in pretty affectation , but she is really laughing at herself all the timehe writes statistical articles for the Reviews — percentages and all those things . He 's just the sort of man , if he knew that I was your mother , to work it out that I was more than thirty . The other one , Mr. Devenish — Claude —she looks up and down as beforehe 's rather , rather poetical . He thinks I came straight from heaven — last week .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: jumping upI think I 'd better go straight back to Paris .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: jumping up and catching her firmly by the armsYou will do nothing of the sort . You will take off that hat —she lets go of the arm and begins to take out the pinwhich is a perfect duck , and I do n't know why I did n't say so before —she puts the hat down on the tableand let me take a good look at youshe does so, and kiss youshe does so, and then we 'll go to your room and unpack and have a lovely talk about clothes . And then we 'll have tea .

div.stage: BETTY comes in .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And now here 's Betty coming in to upset all our delightful plans , just when we 've made them .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How are you , Betty ? I 've left school .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Very nicely , thank you , miss . You 've grown .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: patting the top of DELIA 'S headI 'm much taller than she is .... Well , Betty , what is it ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: The two gentlemen , Mr. Baxter and Mr. Devenish , have both called together , ma'am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: excitedOh ! How — how very simultaneous of them !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: eagerlyOh , do let me see them !

lg.l: Darling , you 'll see plenty of them before you 've finished .
What have you done with them ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: They 're waiting in the hall , ma'am , while I said I would see if you were at home .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: All right , Betty . Give me two minutes and then show them out here .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .Exit .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: They can n't do much harm to each other in two minutes .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: taking her hatWell , I 'll go and unpack . You really wo n't mind my coming down afterwards ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Of course not .A little awkwardlyDarling one , I wonder if you 'd mind — just at first — being introduced as my niece . You see , I expect they 're in a bad temper already , having come here together , and we do n't want to spoil their day entirely .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: smilingI 'll be your mother if you like .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh no , that would n't do , because then Mr. Baxter would feel that he ought to ask your permission before paying his attentions to me . He 's just that sort of man . A niece is so safe — however good you are at statistics , you can n't really prove anything .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: All right , mummy .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: enjoying herselfYou 'd like to be called by a different name , would n't you ? There 's something so thrilling about taking a false name . Such a lot of adventures begin like that . How would you like to be Miss Robinson , darling ? It 's a nice easy one to remember .Persuasively .And you shall put your hair up so as to feel more disguised . What fun we 're going to have !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You baby ! All right , then , I 'm Miss Robinson , your favourite niece .She moves towards the house .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How sweet of you ! Oh , I 'm coming with you to do your hair . You do n't think you 're going to be allowed to do it yourself , when so much depends on it , and husbands leave you because of it , and —They do in together .

div.stage: BETTY comes from the other side of the house into the garden , followed by MR. BAXTER and MR. DEVENISH . MR. BAXTER is forty-five , prim and erect , with close-trimmed moustache and side-whiskers . His clothes are dark and he wears a bowler-hat . MR. DEVENISH is a long-haired , good-looking boy in a négligé costume ; perhaps twenty-two years old , and very scornful of the world .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: looking about her surprisedThe mistress was here a moment ago . I expect she 'll be back directly , if you 'll just wait .She goes back into the house .

div.stage: MR. BAXTER puts his bowler-hat firmly on his head and sits down very stiffly and upright in a chair on the left-hand side of the table . DEVENISH throws his felt hat on to the table and walks about inquisitively . He sees the review in the hammock and picks it up .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Good heavens , Baxter , she 's been reading your article !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I dare say she 's not the only one .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: That 's only guessworkgoing to back of table; you do n't know of anyone else .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: How many people , may I ask , have bought your poems ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: loftilyI do n't write for the mob .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I think I may say that of my own work .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Baxter , I do n't want to disappoint you , but I have reluctantly come to the conclusion that you are one of the mob .Annoyed .Dash it ! what are you doing in the country at all in a bowler-hat ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: If I wanted to be personal , I could say , “ Why do n't you get your hair cut ? ” Only that form of schoolboy humour does n't appeal to me .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: This is not a personal matter ; I am protesting on behalf of nature . What do the birds and the flowers and the beautiful trees think of your hat ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: If one began to ask oneself what the birds thought of things —He pauses .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Well , and why should n't one ask oneself ? It is better than asking oneself what the Stock Exchange thinks of things .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Welllooking up at DEVENISH 'S extravagant hair, it 's the nesting season . Your hair !Suddenly .Ha ! ha ! ha ! ha ! ha ! ha !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: hastily smoothing it downReally , Baxter , you 're vulgar .He turns away and resumes his promenading . Suddenly he sees his book on the grass beneath the hammock and makes a dash for it .Ha , my book !Gloating over itBaxter , she reads my book .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I suppose you gave her a copy .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: exultinglyYes , I gave her a copy . My next book will be hers and hers alone .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Then let me say that , in my opinion , you took a very great liberty .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Liberty ! And this from a man who is continually forcing his unwelcome statistics upon her .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: At any rate , I flatter myself that there is no suggestion of impropriety in anything that I write .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I 'm not so sure about that , Baxter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: What do you mean , sir ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Did you read The Times this month on the new reviews !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Well !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Oh , nothing . It just said , “ Mr. Baxter 's statistics are extremely suggestive . ” I have n't read them , so of course I do n't know what you 've been up to .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: turning away in disgustPah !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Poor old Baxter !He wanders about the garden again , and , having picked a flower , comes to rest against one of the trees from which the hammock is swung . He leans against this and regards the flower thoughtfully .Baxter —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: crosslyI wish you would n't keep calling me “ Baxter . ”

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Harold .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: It is only by accident — an accident which we both deplore — that we have met at all , and in any case I am a considerably older man than yourself .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Mr. Baxter — father — I have a proposal to make . We will leave it to this beautiful flower to decide which of us the lady loves .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: turning roundEh ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: pulling off the petalsShe loves me , she loves Mr. Baxter , she loves me , she loves Mr. Baxter — Heaven help her !— she loves me —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: at the garden door .What are you doing , Mr. Devenish !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: throwing away the flower and bowing very lowMy lady .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: removing his bowler-hat stifflyGood afternoon , Mrs. Tremayne .

div.stage: She gives her left hand to DEVENISH , who kisses it , and her right to BAXTER , who shakes it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How nice of you both to come !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Mr. Devenish and I are inseparable — apparently .

lg.l: You have n't told me what you were doing , Mr. Devenish . Was it
“ This year , next year ? ” or “ Silk , satin — ”

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: My lady , it was even more romantic than that . I have the honour to announce to your ladyship that Mr. Baxter is to be a sailor .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to BAXTERDoes n't he talk nonsense ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: He 'll grow out of it . I did .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , I hope not . I love talking nonsense , and I 'm ever so old .As they both start forward to protestNow which one of you will say it first ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: You are as old as the stars and as young as the dawn .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: You are ten years younger than I am .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: What sweet things to say ! I do n't know which I like best .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Where will my lady sit ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I will recline in the hammock , an it please thee , my lord — only it 's rather awkward getting in , Mr. Baxter . Perhaps you 'd both better look at the tulips for a moment .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Oh — ah — yes .He puts his hat on and turns his back to the hammock .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: leaning over herIf only —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You 'd better not say anything , Mr. Devenish . Keep it for your next volume .He turns away .One , two , three — that was better than last time .They turn round to see her safely in the hammock . DEVENISH leans against the tree at her feet , and BAXTER draws the chair from the right side of the table and turns it round towards her . He presses his hat more firmly on and sits down .I wonder if either of you can guess what I 've been reading this afternoon !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: looking at her lovinglyI know .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: giving him a fleeting lookHow did you know ?to BAXTERYes , Mr. Baxter , it was your article I was reading . If you 'd come five minutes earlier you 'd have found me wrestling — I mean revelling in it .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I am very greatly honoured , Mrs. Tremayne . Ah — it seemed to me a very interesting curve showing the rise and fall of —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I had n't got up to the curves . They are interesting , are n't they ? They are really more in Mr. Devenish 's line .To DEVENISH .Mr. Devenish , it was a great disappointment to me that all the poems in your book seemed to be written to somebody else .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: It was before I met you , lady . They were addressed to the goddess of my imagination . It is only in these last few weeks that I have discovered her .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And discovered she was dark and not fair .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: She will be dark in my next volume .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , how nice of her !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: kindlyYou should write a real poem to Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: excitedlyOh do ! “ To Belinda . ” I do n't know what rhymes , except cinder . You could say your heart was like a cinder — all burnt up .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: painedOh , my lady , I 'm afraid that is a cockney rhyme .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How thrilling ! I 've never been to Hampstead Heath .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: “ Belinda . ” It is far too beautiful to rhyme with anything but itself .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Fancy ! But what about Tremayne ?Singing .Oh , I am Mrs. Tremayne , and I do n't want to marry again .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: protestingMy lady !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: protestingBelinda !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: pointing excitedly to BAXTERThere , that 's the first time he 's called me Belinda !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Are you serious ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Not as a rule .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: You 're not going to marry again ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , who could I marry ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: and BAXTERtogetherMe !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dropping her eyes modestlyBut this is England .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Mrs. Tremayne , I claim the right of age — of my greater years — to speak first .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Mrs. Tremayne , I —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: kindly to DEVENISHYou can speak afterwards , Mr. Devenish . It 's so awkward when you both speak together .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Mrs. Tremayne , I am a man of substantial position , and perhaps I may say of some repute in serious circles . All that I have , whether of material or mental endowment , I lay at your feet , together with an admiration which I cannot readily put into words . As my wife I think you would be happy , and I feel that with you by my side I could achieve even greater things .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How sweet of you ! But I ought to tell you that I 'm no good at figures .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: protestingMy lady —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I do n't mean what you mean , Mr. Devenish . You wait till it 's your turn .To BAXTER .Yes ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I ask you to marry me , Belinda .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: settling herself happily and closing her eyesO-oh !... Now it 's your turn , Mr. Devenish .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: excitedlyMoney — thank Heaven , I have no money . Reputation — thank Heaven , I have no reputation . What can I offer you ? Dreams — nothing but dreams . Come with me and I will show you the world through my dreams . What can I give you ? Youth , freedom , beauty —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Debts .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: still with her eyes shutYou must n't interrupt , Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Belinda , marry me and I will open your eyes to the beauty of the world . Come to me !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: happilyO-oh ! You 've got such different ways of putting things . How can I choose between you ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Then you will marry one of us ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You know I really ought n't to .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I do n't see why not .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , there 's just a little difficulty in the way .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: What is it ? I will remove it . For you I could remove anything — yes , even Baxter .He looks at BAXTER , who is sitting more solidly than ever in his chair .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And anyhow I should have to choose between you .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: in a whisperChoose me .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: stifflyMrs. Tremayne does not require any prompting . A fair field and let the best man win .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: going across to and slapping the astonished BAXTER on the backAye , let the best man win ! Well spoken , Baxter .To BELINDASend us out into the world upon some knightly quest , lady , and let the victor be rewarded .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I — er — ought to say that I should be unable to go very far . I have an engagement to speak at Newcastle on the 21st .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Baxter , I will take no unfair advantage of you . Let the beard of the Lord Mayor of Newcastle be the talisman that my lady demands ; I am satisfied .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: This sort of thing is entirely contrary to my usual mode of life , but I will not be outfaced by a mere boy .Slapping his bowler-hat on the tableI am prepared .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Speak , lady .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: speaking in a deep , mysterious voiceGentlemen , ye put wild thoughts into my head . In sooth , I am minded to send ye forth upon a quest that is passing strange . Know ye that there is a maid journeyed hither , hight Robinson — whose —in her natural voicewhat 's the old for aunt ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: hopefullyMother 's sister .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You know , I think I shall have to explain this in ordinary language . You wo n't mind very much , will you , Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: It is the spirit of this which matters , not the language which clothes it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so glad you think so . Well , now about Miss Robinson . She 's my niece and she 's just come to stay with me , and — poor girl — she 's lost her father . Absolutely lost him . He disappeared ever such a long time ago , and poor Miss Robinson — Delia — naturally wants to find him . Poor girl ! she can n't think where he is .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: noblyI will find him .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , thank you , Mr. Devenish ; Miss Robinson would be so much obliged .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes — er — but what have we to go upon ? Beyond the fact that his name is Robinson —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I should n't go on that too much . You see , he may easily have changed it by now . He was never very much of a Robinson . Nothing to do with Peter or any of those .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I will find him .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Well , can you tell us what he 's like ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , it 's such a long time since I saw him .Looking down modestly .Of course , I was quite a girl then . The only thing I know for certain is that he has a mole on his left arm about here .She indicates a spot just below the elbow .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: folding his arms and looking nobly upwardsI will find him .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I am bound to inform you , Mrs. Tremayne , that even a trained detective could not give you very much hope in such a case . However , I will keep a look-out for him , and , of course , if —

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Fear not , lady , I will find him .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: annoyedYes , you keep on saying that , but what have you got to go on ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: grandlyFaith ! The faith which moves mountains .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , and this is only just one small mole-hill , Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes , but still —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: S'sh ! here is Miss Robinson . If Mr. Devenish will hold the hammock while I alight — we do n't want an accident — I can introduce you .He helps her to get out .Thank you . Delia darling , this is Mr. Baxter ,— and Mr. Devenish . My niece , Miss Robinson —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How do you do ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Miss Robinson has just come over from France . Mon Dieu , quel pays !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I hope you had a good crossing , Miss Robinson .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , I never mind about the crossing . Aunt Belinda —She stops and smiles .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , dear ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I believe tea is almost ready . I want mine , and I 'm sure Mr. Baxter 's hungry . Mr. Devenish scorns food , I expect .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: hurtWhy do you say that ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Are n't you a poet ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , darling , but that does n't prevent him eating . He 'll be absolutely lyrical over Betty 's sandwiches .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: You wo n't deny me that inspiration , I hope , Miss Robinson .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , let 's go and see what they 're like .DELIA and DEVENISH begin to move towards the house .Mr. Baxter , just a moment .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: secretlyNot a word to her about Mr. Robinson . It must be a surprise for her .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Quite so , I understand .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: That 's right .Raising her voice .Oh , Mr. Devenish .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Tremayne ?He comes back .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: secretlyNot a word to her about Mr. Robinson . It must be a surprise for her .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Of course ! I should n't dream —Indignantly .Robinson ! What an unsuitable name !

div.stage: BAXTER and DELIA are just going into the house .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dismissing DEVENISHAll right , I 'll catch you up .

div.stage: DEVENISH goes after the other two .

Left alone , BELINDA laughs happily to herself , and then begins to look rather aimlessly about her . She picks up her sunshade and opens it . She comes to the hammock , picks out her handkerchief , says , “ Ah , there you are ! ” and puts it away . She goes slowly towards the house , turns her head just as she comes to the door , and comes slowly back again . She stops at the table looking down the garden .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to herselfHave you lost yourself , or something ? No ; the latch is this side .... Yes , that 's right .

div.stage: TREMAYNE comes in . He has been knocking about the world for eighteen years , and is very much a man , though he has kept his manners . His hair is greying a little at the sides , and he looks the forty-odd that he is . Without his moustache and beard he is very different from the boy BELINDA married .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: with his hat in his handI 'm afraid I 'm trespassing .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: winninglyBut it 's such a pretty gardenturns away , dosing her parasol, is n't it ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: rather confusedI-I beg your pardon , I-er —He is wondering if it can possibly be she . BELINDA thinks his confusion is due to the fact that he is trespassing , and hastens to put him at his ease .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I should have done the same myself , you know .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: pulling himself togetherOh , but you must n't think I just came in because I liked the garden —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: clapping her handsNo ; but say you do like it , quick .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: It 's lovely and —He hesitates .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: hopefullyYes ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: with convictionYes , it 's lovely .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with that happy sigh of hersO-oh !... Now tell me what really did happen ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I was on my way to Marytown —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: To where ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Marytown .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , you mean Mariton .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Do I ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes ; we always call it Mariton down here .Earnestly .You do n't mind , do you ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: smilingNot a bit .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Just say it — to see if you 've got it right .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Mariton .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: shaking her headOh no , that 's quite wrong . Try it againWith a rustic accent .Mariton .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Mariton .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , that 's much better ....As if it were he who had interrupted .Well , do go on .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I 'm afraid it is n't much of an apology really . I saw what looked like a private road , but what I rather hoped was n't , and — well , I thought I 'd risk it . I do hope you 'll forgive me .

lg.l: Oh , but I love people seeing my garden . Are you staying in
Mariton ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I think so . Oh yes , decidedly .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , perhaps the next time the road wo n't feel so private .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: How charming of you !He feels he must know .Are you Mrs. Tremayne by any chance ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: nodding to himselfYes .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How did you know ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: hastily inventingThey use you as a sign-post in the village . Past Mrs. Tremayne 's house and then bear to the left —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And you could n't go past it ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I 'm afraid I could n't . Thank you so much for not minding . Well , I must be getting on , I have trespassed quite enough .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: regretfullyAnd you have n't really seen the garden yet .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: If you wo n't mind my going on this way , I shall see some more on my way out .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Please do . It likes being looked at .With the faintest suggestion of demurenessAll pretty things do .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Thank you very much . Er —He hesitates .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: helpfullyYes ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I wonder if you 'd mind very much if I called one day to thank you formally for the lesson you gave me in pronunciation ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: gravelyYes . I almost think you ought to . I think it 's the correct thing to do .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: contentedlyThank you very much , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You 'll come in quite formally by the front-door next time , wo n't you , because — because that seems the only chance of my getting to know your name .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon . My name is — er — er — Robinson .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: laughingHow very odd !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: startledOdd ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes ; we have someone called Robinson staying in the house . I wonder if she is any relation ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: hastilyOh no , no . No , she could n't be . I have no relations called Robinson — not to speak of .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: holding out her handYou must tell me all about your relations when you come and call , Mr. Robinson .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I think we can find something better worth talking about than that .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Do you think so ?He says “ Yes ” with his eyes , bows , and goes off down the garden . BELINDA stays looking after him , then gives that happy sigh of hers , only even more soO-oh !

div.stage: Enter BETTY .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: If you please , ma'am , Miss Delia says , are you coming in to tea ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: looking straight in front of her , and taking no notice of BETTY , in a happy , dreamy voiceBetty ,... about callers .... If Mr. Robinson calls — he 's the handsome gentleman who has n't been here before — you will say , “ Not at home . ” And he will say , “ Oh ! ” And you will say , “ I beg your pardon , sir , was it Mr. Robinson ? ” And he will say , “ Yes ! ” And you will say , “ Oh , I beg your pardon , sir — ”Almost as if she were BETTY , she begins to move towards the house .“ This way — ”she would be smiling an invitation over her shoulder to MR. ROBINSON , if he were there , and she were BETTY— “ please ! ”And the abandoned woman goes in to tea .

div.head: ACT II
div.stage: It is morning in BELINDA 'S hall , a low-roofed , oak-beamed place , comfortably furnished as a sitting-room . There is an inner and an outer front-door , both of which are open .

DEVENISH , who has just rung the bell , is waiting with a bouquet of violets between the two . Midway on the right is a door leading to a small room where hats and coats are kept . A door on the left leads towards the living-rooms .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Good morning , sir .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Good morning . I am afraid this is an unceremonious hour for a call , but my sense of beauty urged me hither in defiance of convention .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: holding up his bouquet to BETTYSee , the dew is yet lingering upon them ; how could I let them wait until this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , sir ; but I think the mistress is out .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: They are not for your mistress ; they are for Miss Delia .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , sir . If you will come in , I 'll see if I can find her .She brings him in and goes away to find DELIA .

div.stage: DEVENISH tries a number of poses about the room for himself and his bouquet , and finally selects one against the right side of the door by which he has just come in .
Enter DELIA from the door on the left .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: shutting the door and going to DEVENISHOh , good morning , Mr. Devenish . I 'm afraid my — er — aunt is out .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I know , Miss Delia , I know .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: She 'll be so sorry to have missed you . It is her day for you , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Her day for me ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Yes ; Mr. Baxter generally comes to-morrow , does n't he ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Miss Delia , if our friendship is to progress at all , it can only be on the distinct understanding that I take no interest whatever in Mr. Baxter 's movements .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so sorry ; I thought you knew . What lovely flowers ! Are they for my aunt ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: To whom does one bring violets ? To modest , shrinking , tender youth .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I do n't think we have anybody here like that .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: with a bowMiss Delia , they are for you .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , how nice of you ! But I 'm afraid I ought n't to take them from you under false pretences ; I do n't shrink .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: A fanciful way of putting it , perhaps . They are none the less for you .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Well , it 's awfully kind of you . I 'm afraid I 'm not a very romantic person . Aunt Belinda does all the romancing in our family .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Your aunt is a very remarkable woman .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: She is . Do n't you dare to say a word against her .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: My dear Miss Delia , nothing could be further from my thoughts . Why , am I not indebted to her for that great happiness which has come to me in these last few days ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: surprisedGood gracious ! and I did n't know anything about it . But what about poor Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: stifflyI must beg that Mr. Baxter 's name be kept out of our conversation .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But I thought Mr. Baxter and you — do tell me what 's happened . I seem to have lost myself .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: What has happened , Miss Delia , is that I have learnt at last the secret that my heart has been striving to tell me for weeks past . As soon as I saw that gracious lady , your aunt , I knew that I was in love . Foolishly I took it for granted that it was she for whom my heart was thrilling . How mistaken I was ! Directly you came , you opened my eyes , and now —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Mr. Devenish , you do n't say you 're proposing to me ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I am . I feel sure I am . Delia , I love you .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How exciting of you !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: with a modest shrugIt 's nothing ; I am a poet .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You really want to marry me ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Such is my earnest wish .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But what about my aunt ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: simplyShe will be my aunt-in-law .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: She 'll be rather surprised .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Delia , I will be frank with you . I admit that I made Mrs. Tremayne an offer of marriage .

sp.speaker: DELIA
