sp.p: excitedlyYou really did ? Was it that first afternoon I came ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , I wish I 'd been there !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: with dignityIt is not my custom to propose in the presence of a third party . It is true that on the occasion you mention a man called Baxter was on the lawn , but I regarded him no more than the old apple-tree or the flower-beds , or any other of the fixtures .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What did she say ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: She accepted me conditionally .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , do tell me !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: It is rather an unhappy story . This man called Baxter in his vulgar way also made a proposal of marriage . Mrs. Tremayne was gracious enough to imply that she would marry whichever one of us fulfilled a certain condition .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How sweet of her !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: It is my earnest hope , Miss Delia , that the man called Baxter will be the victor . As far as is consistent with honour , I shall endeavour to let Mr. Baxterbanging the table with his handwin .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What was the condition ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: That I am not at liberty to tell . It is , I understand , to be a surprise for you .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How exciting !... Mr. Devenish , you have been very frank . May I be equally so ?DEVENISH bows .Why do you wear your hair so long ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: pleasedYou have noticed it ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Well , yes , I have .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I wear it so to express my contempt for the conventions of so-called society .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I always thought that people wore it very very short if they despised the conventions of society .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I think that the mere fact that my hair annoys Mr. Baxter is sufficient justification for its length .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But if it annoys me too ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: heroicallyIt shall go .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: apologeticallyI told you I was n't a very romantic person , did n't I ?Kindly .You can always grow it again if you fall in love with somebody else .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: That is cruel of you , Delia . I shall never fall in love again .

div.stage: Enter BELINDA in a hat .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Why , it 's Mr. Devenish ! How nice of you to come so early in the morning ! How is Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I do not know , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to DELIAI got most of the things , Delia .To DEVENISH .“ The things , ” Mr. Devenish , is my rather stuffy way of referring to all the delightful poems that you are going to eat to-night .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I am looking forward to it immensely , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I do hope I 've got all your and Mr. Baxter 's favourite dishes .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I 'm afraid Mr. Baxter and I are not likely to appreciate the same things .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: coylyOh , Mr. Devenish ! And you were so unanimous a few days ago .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I think Mr. Devenish was referring entirely to things to eat .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I felt quite sad when I was buying the lamb cutlets . To think that , only a few days before , they had been frisking about with their mammas , and having poems written about them by Mr. Devenish . There ! I 'm giving away the whole dinner . Delia , take him away before I tell him any more . We must keep some surprises for him .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: to DEVENISH as she picks up the flowersCome along , Mr. Devenish .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: wickedlyAre those my flowers , Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: after a little hesitation , with a bow which might refer to either of themThey are for the most beautiful lady in the land .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , how nice of you !

div.stage: DEVENISH follows DELIA out through the door on the left .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: unpinning her hat before a mirrorI suppose he means Delia — bless them !She gives a few pats to her hair and then walks about the room singing softly to herself . She does to the front-door and looks happily out into the garden . Suddenly she sees MR. BAXTER approaching . She hurries back into a chair and pretends to be very busy reading .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: rather nervouslyEr — may I come in , Mrs. Tremayne ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dropping her book and turning round with a violent startOh , Mr. Baxter , how you surprised me !She puts her hand to her heart .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I must apologize for intruding upon you at this hour , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: holding up her handStop !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: startledWhat ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I cannot let you come in like that .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: looking down at himselfLike what ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dropping her eyesYou called me Belinda once .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: coming down to herMay I explain my position , Mrs. Tremayne ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Before you begin — have you been seeing my niece lately ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: surprisedNo .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh !Sweetly .Please go on .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Why , is she lost too ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh no ; I just — Do sit down . Let me put your hat down somewhere for you .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: keeping it firmly in his hand , and sitting down on the sofaIt will be all right here , thank you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: returning to her chairI 'm dying to hear what you are going to say .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: First as regards the use of your Christian name . I felt that , as a man of honour , I could not permit myself to use it until I had established my right over that of Mr. Devenish .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: All my friends call me Belinda .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: As between myself and Mr. Devenish the case is somewhat different . Until one of us is successful over the other in the quest upon which you have sent us , I feel that as far as possible we should hold aloof from you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: pleadinglyJust say “ Belinda ” once more , in case you 're a long time .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: very formallyBelinda .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How nicely you say it — Harold .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: half getting out of his seatMrs. Tremayne , I must not listen to this .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: meeklyI wo n't offend again , Mr. Baxter . Please go on . Tell me about the quest ; are you winning ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I am progressing , Mrs. Tremayne . Indeed , I came here this morning to acquaint you with the results of my investigations . Yesterday I located a man called Robinson working upon a farm close by . I ventured to ask him if he had any marks upon him by which he could be recognized . He adopted a threatening attitude , and replied that if I wanted any he could give me some . With the aid of half-a-crown I managed to placate him . Putting my inquiry in another form , I asked if he had any moles . A regrettable misunderstanding , which led to a fruitless journey to another part of the village , was eventually cleared up , and on my return I satisfied myself that this man was in no way related to your niece .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: admiringlyHow splendid of you ! Well , now , we know he 's not .She holds up one finger .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes . In the afternoon I located another Mr. Robinson following the profession of a carrier . My first inquiries led to a similar result , with the exception that in this case Mr. Robinson carried his threatening attitude so far as to take off his coat and roll up his sleeves . Perceiving at once that he was not the man , I withdrew .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How brave you are ! That makes two .She holds up another fingerIt still leaves a good many .Pleadingly .Just call me Belinda again .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: nervouslyYou must n't tempt me , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: penitentlyI wo n't !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: To resume , then , my narrative . This morning I have heard of a third Mr. Robinson . Whether there is actually any particular fortune attached to the number three I cannot say for certain . It is doubtful whether statistics would be found to support the popular belief . But one likes to flatter oneself that in one 's own case it may be true ; and so —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And so the third Mr. Robinson —?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Something for which I cannot altogether account inspires me with hope . He is , I have discovered , staying at Mariton . This afternoon I go to look for him .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to herselfMariton ! How funny ! I wonder if it 's the same one .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: What one ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , just one of the ones .Gratefully .Mr. Baxter , you are doing all this for me .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Pray do not mention it . I do n't know if it 's Devonshire , or the time of the year , or the sort of atmosphere you create , Mrs. Tremayne , but I feel an entirely different man . There is something in the air which — yes , I shall certainly go over to Mariton this afternoon .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: gravelyI have had the same feeling sometimes , Mr. Baxter . I am not always the staid respectable matron which I appear to you to be . Sometimes I —She looks absently at the watch on her wrist .Good gracious !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: alarmedWhat is it !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: looking anxiously from the door to himMr. Baxter , I 'm going to throw myself on your mercy .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Tremayne —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: looking at her watch againA strange man will be here directly . He must not find you with me .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: rising , jealouslyA man ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: excitedlyYes , yes , a man ! He is pursuing me with his attentions . If he found you here , there would be a terrible scene .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I will defend you from him .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No , no . He is a big man . He will — he will overpower you .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But you —?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I can defend myself . I will send him away . But he must not find you here . You must hide before he overpowers you .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: with dignityI will withdraw if you wish it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No , not withdraw , hide . He might see you withdrawing .Leading the way to a door on the rightQuick , in here .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: embarrassed at the thought that this sort of thing really only happens in a bedroom farceI do n't think I quite —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reassuring himIt 's perfectly respectable ; it 's where we keep the umbrellas .She takes him by the hand .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: still resistingI 'm not at all sure that I —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: earnestlyOh , but do n't you see what trust I 'm putting in you ? Some people are so nervous about their umbrellas .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Well , of course , if you — but I do n't see why I should n't just slip out of the door before he comes .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reproachfullyOf course , if you grudge me every little pleasure — Quick ! Here he is .

div.stage: She bundles him through the door , and with a sigh of happiness comes back and looks at herself in the mirror . She goes to the front-door , moves her hand to somebody in the distance , and comes into the hall again . Seeing MR. BAXTER 'S bowler hat on the sofa , she carries across to his door , knocks , hands it to him , saying , “ Your hat . S'sh ! ” and returns to her chair . TREMAYNE comes in .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: at the doorIt 's no good your pretending to be surprised , because you said I could come .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: welcoming himBut I can still be surprised that you wanted to come .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE O
sp.p: h no , you are n't .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: marking it off on her fingersJust a little bit — that much .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: It would be much more surprising if I had n't come .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sitting down on the sofaIt is a pretty garden , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: sitting down next to herYou forget that I saw the garden yesterday .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , but the things have grown so much since then . Let me see , this is the third day you 've been and we only met three days ago . And then you 're coming to dinner again to-night .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: eagerlyAm I ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes . Have n't you been asked ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: No , not a word .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , that 's quite right ; I remember now , I only thought of it this morning , so I could n't ask you before , could I ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: earnestlyWhat made you think of it then ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: romanticallyIt was at the butcher 's . There was one little lamb cutlet left over and sitting out all by itself , and there was nobody to love it . And I said to myself , suddenly , “ I know , that will do for Mr. Robinson . ”Prosaically .I do hope you like lamb ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I adore it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so glad ! When I saw it sitting there I thought you 'd love it . I 'm afraid I can n't tell you any more about the rest of the dinner , because I would n't tell Mr. Devenish , and I want to be fair .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Who 's Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , have n't you met him ? He 's always coming here .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE I
sp.p: s he in love with you too ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Too ? Oh , you mean Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Confound it , that 's three !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: innocentlyThree ?She looks up at him and down again .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Who is Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , have n't you met him ? He 's always coming here .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Who is Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , he 's a sort of statistician . Is n't that a horrid word to say ? So stishany .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What does he make statistics about ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , umbrellas and things . Do n't let 's talk about him .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: All right , then ; who is Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , he 's a poet .She throws up her eyes and sighs deeply .Ah me !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What does he write poetry about ?BELINDA looks at him , and down again , and then at him again , and then down , and gives a little sigh — all of which means , “ Ca n't you guess ? ”What does he write poetry about ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: obedientlyHe wrote “ The Lute of Love and other Poems , by Claude Devenish . ” The Lute of Love —To herself .I have n't been saying that lately .With great expression .The Lute of Love — the Lute .She pats her mouth back .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: And what is Mr. Devenish —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: putting her hand on his sleeveYou 'll let me know when it 's my turn , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Your turn ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , to ask questions . I love this game — it 's like clumps .She crosses her hands on her lap and waits for the next question .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I — er — of course have no right to cross-examine you like this .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , do go on , I love it .With childish excitement .I 've got my question ready .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: smilingI think perhaps it is your turn .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: eagerlyIs it really ?He nods .Well then — who is Mr. Robinson ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: alarmedWhat ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I think it 's a fair question . I met you three days ago and you told me you were staying at Mariton . Mariton . You can say it all right now , can n't you ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I think so .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: coaxinglyJust say it .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Mariton .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: clapping her handsLovely ! I do n't think any of the villagers do it as well as that .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , that was three days ago . You came the next day to see the garden , and you came the day after to see the garden , and you 've come this morning — to see the garden ; and you 're coming to dinner to-night , and it 's so lovely , we shall simply have to go into the garden afterwards . And all I know about you is that you have n't any relations called Robinson .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What do I know about Mrs. Tremayne but that she has a relation called Robinson ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And two dear friends called Devenish and Baxter .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: annoyedI was forgetting them .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to herselfI must n't forget Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: getting upBut what does it matter ? What would it matter if I knew nothing about you ? I know everything about you — everything that matters .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: closing her eyes contentedlyTell me some of them .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: bending over her earnestlyBelinda —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: still with her eyes shutHe 's going to propose to me . I can feel it coming .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Confound it ! how many men have proposed to you ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: surprisedSince when ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Since your first husband proposed to you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , I thought you meant this year .Sitting up .Well now , let me see .Slowly and thoughtfully .One .She pushes up her first finger .Two .She pushes up the second .Three .She pushes up the third finger , holds it there for a moment and then pushes it gently down again .No , I do n't think that one ought to count really .She pushes up two more fingers and the thumb .Three , four , five — do you want the names or just the total ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: This is horrible .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: innocentlyBut anybody can propose . Now if you 'd asked how many I 'd accepted — Let me see , where was I up to ? I sha n't count yours , because I have n't really had it yet . Six , seven — Yes , Betty , what is it ?

div.stage: BETTY has just come in from the door on the left .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: If you please , ma'am , cook would like to speak to you for a minute .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: getting upYes , I 'll come .To TREMAYNE .You 'll forgive me , wo n't you ? You 'll find some cigarettes there .She starts to go , but comes back and adds confidentiallyIt 's probably about the lamb cutlets ; I expect your little one refuses to be cooked .

div.stage: She goes out after BETTY .

Left alone , TREMAYNE stalks moodily about the room , occasionally kicking things which come in his way . He takes up his hat suddenly and goes towards the door ; stops irresolutely and comes back . He is standing in the middle of the room with his hands in his pockets when DEVENISH comes in from the door on the left .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: surprisedHullo !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE H
sp.p: ullo !... Are you Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Devenish the poet ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: coming up and shaking him warmly by the handMy dear fellow , you know my work ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: grimlyMy dear Mr. Devenish , your name is most familiar to me .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I congratulate you . I thought your great-grandchildren would be the first to hear of me .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: My name 's Robinson , by the way .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Then let me return the compliment , Robinson . Your name is familiar to me .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: hastilyI do n't think I 'm related to any Robinsons you know .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Well , no , I suppose not . When I was very much younger I began a collection of Robinsons . Actually it was only three days ago , but it seems much longer . Many things have happened since then .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: uninterestedReally !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: There is a man called Baxter who is still collecting , I believe . For myself , I am only interested in one of the great family — Delia .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: eagerlyYou are interested in her ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Devotedly . In fact , I am at this moment waiting for her to put on her hat .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: warmlyMy dear Devenish , I am delighted to make your acquaintance .He seizes his hand and grips it heartily .How are you ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: feeling his fingersFairly well , thanks .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: That 's right .They sit on the sofa together .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: still nursing his handYou are a very lucky fellow , Robinson .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: In what way ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: People you meet must be so very reluctant to say good-bye to you . Have you ever tried strangling lions or anything like that ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: with a laughWell , as a matter of fact , I have .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I suppose you won all right ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: In the end , with the help of my beater .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Personally I should have backed you alone against any two ordinary lions .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: One was quite enough . As it was , he gave me something to remember him by .Putting up his left sleeve , he displays a deep scar .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: looking at it casuallyBy Jove , that 's a nasty one !He suddenly catches sight of the mole and stares at it fascinated .Good heavens !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: clasping his headWait . Let me think .After a pause .Have you ever met a man called Baxter ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Would you like to ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: grimlyVery much indeed .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: He 's the man I told you about who 's interested in Robinsons . He 'll be delighted to meet you .With a nervous laugh .Funny thing , he 's rather an authority on lions . You must show him that scar of yours ; it will intrigue him immensely .Earnestly .Do n't shake hands with him too heartily just at first ; it might put him off the whole thing .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: This Mr. Baxter seems to be a curious man .

sp.speaker: DIVENISH
sp.p: absentlyYes , he is rather odd .Looking at his watch .I wonder if I —To TREMAYNE .I suppose you wo n't be —He stops suddenly . A slight tapping noise comes from the room where they keep umbrellas .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What 's that !

div.stage: The tapping noise is repeated , a little more loudly this time .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Come in .

div.stage: The door opens and BAXTER comes in nervously , holding his bowler hat in his hand .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Oh , I just —TREMAYNE stands up— I just —He goes back again .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: springing across the roomBaxter !The door opens nervously again and BAXTER 'S head appears round it .Come in , Baxter , old man ; you 're just the very person I wanted .BAXTER comes in carefully .Good man .To TREMAYNEThis is Mr. Baxter that I was telling you about .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: much relieved at the appearance of his rivalOh , is this Mr. Baxter ?Holding out his hand with great friendlinessHow are you , Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: warninglySteady !TREMAYNE shakes BAXTER quite gently by the hand .Baxter , this is Mr. Robinson .Casually .R-o-b-i-n-s-o-n .He looks sideways at BAXTER to see how he takes it . BAXTER is noticeably impressed .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Really ? I am very glad to meet you , sir .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Very good of you to say so .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: to BAXTERRobinson is a great big-game hunter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Indeed ? I have never done anything in that way myself , but I 'm sure it must be an absorbing pursuit .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh , well , it 's something to do .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: to BAXTERYou must get him to tell you about a wrestle he had with a lion once . Extraordinary story !Looking at his watch suddenly .Jove ! I must be off . See you again , Baxter . Good-bye , Robinson . No , do n't shake hands . I 'm in a hurry .He looks at his watch again and goes out hurriedly by the door on the left .

div.stage: TREMAYNE sit down together on the sofa .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Unusual man , your friend Devenish . I suppose it comes of being a poet .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I have no great liking for Mr. Devenish —

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh , he 's all right .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But I am sure that if he is impressed by anything outside himself or his own works , it must be something rather remarkable . Pray tell me of your adventure with the lion .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: laughingReally , you must n't think that I go about telling everybody my adventures . It just happened to come up . I 'm afraid I shook his hand rather more warmly than I meant , and he asked me if I 'd ever tried strangling lions . That was all .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: And had you ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Well , it just happened that I had .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Indeed ! You came off scathless , I trust ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: carelessly indicating his armWell , he got me one across there .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: obviously excitedReally , really . One across there . Not bad , I hope ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: laughingWell , it does n't show unless I do that .He pulls up his sleeve carelessly and BAXTER bends eagerly over his arm .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Good heavens ! I 've found it !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Found what ?He pulls down his sleeve .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I must see Mrs. Tremayne . Where 's Mrs. Tremayne ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: She went out just now . What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Out ! I must find her . This is a matter of life and death .He seizes his hat and hurries out by the front door .

div.stage: TREMAYNE stares after him in amazement . Then he pulls up his sleeve , looks at his scar again and shakes his head . While he is still puzzling over it , BELINDA comes back .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Such a to-do in the kitchen ! The cook 's given notice — at least she will directly — and your lamb cutlet slipped back to the shop when nobody was looking , and I 've got to go into the village again , and oh dear , oh dear , I have such a lot of things to do !Looking across at MR. BAXTER 'S door .Oh yes , that 's another one . Mr. Robinson , you will have to leave me . Farewell .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Belinda —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No , not even Belinda . Wait till this evening .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I have a thousand things to say to you ; I shall say them this evening .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: giving him her handBegin about eight o'clock . Good-bye till then .

div.stage: He takes her hand , looks at her for a moment , then suddenly bends and kisses it , and out .

BELINDA stands looking from her hand to him , gives a little wondering exclamation and then presses the back of her hand against her cheek , and goes to the swing doors . She turns back , and remembers MR. BAXTER again . With a smile she goes to the door and taps gently .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Mr. Baxter , Mr. Baxter , you may come in now ; he has withdrawn . I have unhanded him .She opens the door and finds the room empty .Oh !

div.stage: BAXTER comes in at the front door .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Ah , there you are !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: turning with a startOh , how you frightened me , Mr. Baxter ! I could n't think what had happened to you . I thought perhaps you 'd been eaten up by one of the umbrellas .

lg.l: Mrs. Tremayne , I have some wonderful news for you . I have found
Miss Robinson 's father .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: hardly understandingMiss Robinson 's father ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes . Mr. Robinson .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , you mean — Oh yes , he told me his name was Robinson — Oh , but he 's no relation .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Wait ! I saw his arm . By a subterfuge I managed to see his arm .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: her eyes opening more and more widely as she begins to realizeYou saw —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I saw the mole .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: faintly as she holds out her own armShow me .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: very decorously indicatingThere !

div.stage: BELINDA holds the place with her other hand , and still looking at MR. BAXTER , slowly begins to laugh — half-laughter , half-tears , wonderingly , happily , contentedly .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And I did n't know !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Mrs. Tremayne , I am delighted to have done this service for your niece —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to herselfOf course , he knew all the time .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: to the worldStill more am I delighted to have gained the victory over Mr. Devenish in this enterprise .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Eighteen years — but I ought to have known .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: at largeI shall not be accused of exaggerating when I say that the odds against such an enterprise were enormous .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Eighteen years — And now I 've eight whole hours to wait !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: triumphantlyIt will be announced to-night . “ Mr. Devenish , ” I shall say , “ young fellow — ”He arranges his speech in his mind .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: So I was right , after all !Slowly and triumphantly .He does look better without a beard !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: making his speech“ Mr. Devenish , young fellow , when you matched yourself against a man of my repute , when you matched yourself against a man ” —BELINDA has slipped out , to enjoy her happiness alone— “ who has read papers at soirées of the Royal Statistical Society ; when — er — ”

div.stage: He looks round the room and discovers to his amazement that he is alone . He claps on his bowler-hat , gives another amazed look round , says with a shrug , “ Unusual ! ” and goes out .

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: It is after dinner in BELINDA 'S hall . BELINDA is lying on the sofa with a coffee-cup in her hand . DELIA , in the chair on the right , has picked up “ The Lute of Love ” from a table and is reading it impatiently .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What rubbish he writes !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: coming back from her thoughtsWho , dear ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Claude — Mr. Devenish . Of course , he 's very young .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: So was Keats , darling .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I do n't think Claude has had Keats ’ advantages . Keats started life as an apothecary .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: So much nicer than a chemist .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Now , Claude started with nothing to do .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: mildlyDo you always call him Claude , darling ? I hope you are n't going to grow into a flirt like that horrid Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Silly mother !SeriouslyI do n't think he 'll ever be any good till he really gets work . Did you notice his hair this evening ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dreamilyWhose , dear ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Mummy , look me in the eye and tell me you are not being bad .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: innocentlyBad , darling ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You 've made Mr. Robinson fall in love with you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: happilyHave I ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Yes ; it 's serious this time . He 's not like the other two .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: However did you know that ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , I know .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Darling , I believe you 've grown up . It 's quite time I settled down .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: With Mr. Robinson ?

div.stage: BELINDA looks thoughtfully at DELIA for a little time and then sits up .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: mysteriouslyDelia , are you prepared for a great secret to be revealed to you ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: childishlyOh , I love secrets .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reproachfullyDarling , you must n't take it like that . This is a great , deep , dark secret ; you 'll probably need your sal volatile .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: excitedlyGo on !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well —Looking round the room .Shall we have the lights down a little ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Go on , mummy .

lg.l: Well , Mr. Robinson is —
— is not quite the
Robinson he appears to be .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: In fact , child , he is — Had n't you better come and hold your mother 's hand ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: struggling with some emotionGo on .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , Mr. Robinson is a — sort of relation of yours ; in fact —playing with her rings and looking down coyly— he is your — father .She looks up at DELIA to see how the news is being received .Dear one , this is not a matter for mirth .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: coming over and kissing herDarling , it is lovely , is n't it ? I am laughing because I am so happy .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Are n't you surprised ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: No . You see , Claude told me this morning . He found out just before Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well ! Every one seems to have known except me .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Did n't you see how friendly father and I got at dinner ? I thought I 'd better start breaking the ice — because I suppose he 'll be kissing me directly .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Say you like him .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: I think he 's going to be awfully nice . Does he know you know ?She goes back to her seat .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Not yet . Just at present I 've rather got Mr. Baxter on my mind . I suppose , darling , you would n't like him as well as Mr. Devenish !Pathetically .You see , they 're so used to going about together .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Claude is quite enough .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I think I must see Mr. Baxter and get it over . Do you mind if I have Mr. Devenish too ? I feel more at home with both of them . I 'll give you him back . Oh dear , I feel so happy to-night !She jumps up and goes over to DELIA .And is my little girl going to be happy too ? That 's what mothers always say on the stage . I think it 's so sweet .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: smiling at herYes , I think so , mummy . Of course , I 'm not romantic like you . I expect I 'm more like father , really .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dreamilyJack can be romantic now . He was telling me this morning all about the people he has proposed to . I mean , I was telling him . Anyhow , he was n't a bit like a father . Of course , he does n't know he is a father yet . Darling , I think you might take him into the garden ; only do n't let him know who he is . You see , he ought to propose to me first , ought n't he ?As the men come in , she gets up .Here you all are ! I do hope you have n't been throwing away your cigars , because smoking is allowed all over the house .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh , we 've finished , thank you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Is n't it a wonderful night ?— and so warm for April . Delia , you must show Mr. Robinson the garden by moonlight — it 's the only light he has n't seen it by .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: quicklyI do n't think I 've ever seen it by moonlight , Miss Delia .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I thought poets were always seeing things by moonlight .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I was hoping , Mrs. Tremayne , that — er — perhaps —

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Come along , Mr. Robinson .

div.stage: TREMAYNE looks at BELINDA , who gives him a nod .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: It 's very kind of you , Miss Robinson . I suppose there is no chance of a nightingale ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: There ought to be . I ordered one specially for Mr. Devenish .DELIA and TREMAYNE go out together . BELINDA settles herself comfortably on the sofa .Now we 're together again . Well , Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Er — I —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No ; I think I 'll let Mr. Baxter speak first . I know he 's longing to .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes . H'r ' m ! Mrs. Tremayne , I beg formally to claim your hand .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sweetlyOn what grounds , Mr. Baxter ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: spiritedlyYes , sir , on what grounds ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: On the grounds that , as I told you this morning , I had succeeded in the quest .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: appearing to be greatly surprisedSucceeded ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Devenish , young fellow , you have lost . I have discovered the missing Mr. Robinson .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Who — where —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: dramaticallyMiss Robinson has at this moment gone out with her father .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Good heavens ! It was he !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sympatheticallyPoor Mr. Devenish !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: pointing tragically to the tableAnd to think that I actually sat on that table — no , that seat — no , not that one , it was the sofa — that I sat on the sofa with him this morning , and never guessed ! Why , ten minutes ago I was asking him for the nuts !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Aha , Devenish , you 're not so clever as you thought you were .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Why , I must have given you the clue myself ! He told me he had a scar on his arm , and I never thought any more of it . And then I went away innocently and left you two talking about it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: alarmedA scar on his arm ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Where a lion mauled him .

div.stage: BELINDA gives a little shudder .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: It 's quite healed up now , Mrs. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: looking at him admiringlyA lion ! What you two have adventured for my sake !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: I suppose you will admit , Devenish , that I may fairly claim to have won ?

div.stage: Looking the picture of despair , DEVENISH droops his head , raises his arms and lets them fall hopelessly to his sides .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Mr. Devenish , I have never admired you so much as I do at this moment .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: indignantly to DEVENISHI say , you know , that 's not fair . It 's all very well to take your defeat like a man , but you must n't overdo it . Mrs. Tremayne , I claim the reward which I have earned .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: after a pauseMr. Baxter — Mr. Devenish , I have something to tell you .Penitently .I have not been quite frank with you . I think you both ought to know that — I — I made a mistake . Delia is not my niece ; she is my daughter .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Your daughter ! I say , how ripping !

div.stage: BELINDA gives him an understanding look .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Your daughter !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But — but you are n't old enough to have a daughter of that age .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: apologeticallyWell , there she is .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But — but she 's grown up .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Quite .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Then in that case you must be —He hesitates , evidently working it out .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: hastilyI 'm afraid so , Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But this makes a great difference . I had no idea . Why , when I 'm fifty you would be —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: sighingYes , I suppose I should .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: And when I 'm sixty —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: pleadingly to DEVENISHCa n't you stop him ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Look here , Baxter , another word from you and you 'll never get to sixty .

lg.l: And then there 's Miss — er — Delia . In the event of our marrying ,
Mrs. Tremayne , she , I take it , would be my step-daughter .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I do n't think she would trouble us much , Mr. Baxter . I have an idea that she will be getting married before long .She glances at DEVENISH , who returns her look gratefully .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: None the less , the fact would be disturbing . I have never yet considered myself seriously as a step-father . I do n't think I am going too far if I say that to some extent I have been deceived in this matter .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: reproachfullyAnd so have I. I thought you loved me .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: sympatheticallyYes , yes .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: turning to him suddenlyAnd Mr. Devenish too .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Er —

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Er —

div.stage: They stand before her guiltily and have nothing to say .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a shrugWell , I shall have to marry somebody else , that 's all .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I suppose Mr. Robinson . After all , if I am Delia 's mother , and Mr. Baxter says that Mr. Robinson 's her father , it 's about time we were married .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: eagerlyMrs. Tremayne , what fools we are ! He is your husband all the time !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: You 've had a husband all the time ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: apologeticallyI lost him ; it was n't my fault .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Really , this is very confusing . I do n't know where I am . I gather — I am to gather , it seems , that you are no longer eligible as a possible wife ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I am afraid not , Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But this is very confusing — this is very disturbing to a man of my age . For weeks past I have been regarding myself as a — a possible benedict . I have — ah — taken steps . Only this morning , in writing to my housekeeper , I warned her that she might hear at any moment a most startling announcement .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: cheerfullyOh , that 's all right . That might only mean that you were getting a new bowler-hat .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: suddenlyAh , and what about you , sir ? How is it that you take this so lightly ?Triumphantly .I have it . It all becomes clear to me . You have transferred your affections to her daughter !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Oh , I say , Baxter , this is very crude .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: And why should he not , Mr. Baxter ?Softly .He has made me very happy .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: He has made you happy , Mrs. Tremayne !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Very happy .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: thoughtfullyAh !He takes a turn round the room in , silence , and then comes back to her .Mrs. Tremayne , I have taken a great resolve .Solemnly .I also will make you happy .Thumping his heart .I also will woo Miss Delia .Suddenly seizing DEVENISH 'S armCome , we will seek Miss Delia together . It may be that she will send us upon another quest in which I shall again be victorious .TempestuouslyCome , I say !He marches the resisting DEVENISH to the swing doors .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: to BELINDAPlease !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: gentlyMr. Baxter ... Harold .BAXTER stops and turns round .You are too impetuous . I think that as Delia 's mother —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Your pardon , Mrs. Tremayne . In the intoxication of the moment I am forgetting .Formally .I have the honour to ask your permission to pay my addresses —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: No , no , I did n't mean that . But , as Delia 's mother , I ought to warn you that she is hardly fitted to take the place of your housekeeper . She is not very domesticated .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: indignantlyNot domesticated ? Why , did I not hear her tell her father at dinner that she had arranged all the flowers ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: There are other things than flowers .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Bed-socks , for instance , Baxter . It 's a very tricky thing airing bed-socks . I am sure your house-keeper —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Mrs. Tremayne , she will learn . The daughter of such a mother ... I need say no more .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , thank you . But there is something else , Mr. Baxter . You are not being quite fair to yourself . In starting out upon this simultaneous wooing , you forget that Mr. Devenish has already had his turn this morning alone . You should have yours ... alone ... too .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Oh , I say !

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes , yes , you are right . I must introduce myself first as a suitor . I see that .To DEVENISHYou stay here ; I will go alone into the garden , and —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: It is perhaps a little cold out of doors for people of ... of our age , Mr. Baxter . Now , in the library —

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: astonishedLibrary ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: You have a library ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: to DEVENISHHe does n't believe I have a library .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: You ought to see the library , Baxter .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: But you are continually springing surprises on me this evening , Mrs. Tremayne . First a daughter , then a husband , and then — a library ! I have been here three weeks , and I never knew you had a library . Dear me , I wonder how it is that I never saw it ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: modestlyI thought you came to see me .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: Yes , yes , to see you , certainly . But if I had known you had a library ....

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh , I am so glad I mentioned it . Was n't it lucky , Mr. Devenish ?

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: My work has been greatly handicapped of late by lack of certain books to which I wanted to refer . It would be a great help —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: My dear Mr. Baxter , my whole library is at your disposal .To DEVENISH , as she leads the way to the door , in a confidential whisper .I 'm just going to show him the “ Encyclopedia Britannica . ”She smiles at him , and he opens the door for them both . Then he goes towards the garden door and looks outside .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: from the gardenHullo , we 're just coming in .He goes back and waits for them .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Where 's Mrs. Tremayne ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: She 's gone to the library with Baxter .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: carelesslyOh , the library . Where 's that ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: promptly going towards the door and opening itThe end door on the right . Right at the end . You can n't mistake it . On the right .

lg.l: Ah , yes .
Yes .
Yes .

div.stage: DEVENISH hastily shuts the door and comes back to DELIA .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I say , your mother is a ripper .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: enthusiasticallyIs n't she !Remembering .At least , you mean my aunt ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: smiling at herNo , I mean your mother . To think that I once had the cheek to propose to her .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh ! Is it cheek to propose to people !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: To her .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But not to me ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Oh I say , Delia !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: with great dignityThank you , my name is Miss Robinson — I mean , Tremayne .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Well , if you 're not quite sure which it is , it 's much safer to call you Delia .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: smilingWell , perhaps it is .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: And if I did propose to you , you have n't answered

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: If you want an answer now , it 's no ; but if you like to wait till next April —

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: reproachfullyOh , I say , and I cut my hair for you the same afternoon . You have n't really told me how you like it yet .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Oh , how bad of me ! You look lovely .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: And I promised to give up poetry for your sake .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Perhaps I ought n't to have asked you that .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: As far as I 'm concerned , Delia , I 'll do it gladly , but , of course , one has to think about posterity .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: But you need n't be a poet . You could give posterity plenty to think about if you were a statesman .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I do n't quite see your objection to poetry .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You would be about the house so much . I want you to go away every day and do great things , and then come home in the evening and tell me all about it .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Then you are thinking of marrying me !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: Well , I was just thinking in case I had to .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: It would be rather fun if you did . And look here — I will be a statesman , if you like , and go up to Downing Street every day , and come back in the evening and tell you all about it .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: How nice of you !

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: magnificently , holding up his hand to HeavenFarewell , Parnassus !

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Well , it means that I 've chucked poetry . A statesman 's life is the life for me ; behold Mr. Devenish , the new M. P .— no , look here , that was quite accidental .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: smiling at himI believe I shall really like you when I get to know you .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I do n't know if it 's you , or Devonshire , or the fact that I 've had my hair cut , but I feel quite a different being from what I was three days ago .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You are different . Perhaps it 's your sense of humour coming back .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Perhaps that 's it . It 's a curious feeling .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: holding out her handLet 's go outside ; there 's a heavenly moon .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: taking her handMoon ? Moon ? Now where have I heard that word before ?

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: I was trying not to be a poet . Well , I 'll come with you , but I shall refuse to look at it .Putting his left hand behind his back , he walks slowly out with her , saying to himselfThe Prime Minister then left the House .

div.stage: BELINDA and TREMAYNE come from the library .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: as he opens the doorThank you . I do n't think it 's unkind to leave him , do you ? He seemed quite happy .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I should n't have been happy if we 'd stayed .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: going to the sofa and putting her feet upYes , but I was really thinking of Mr. Baxter .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Not of me ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , I thought it was Mr. Baxter 's turn . Poor man , he 's had a disappointment lately .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: eagerlyA disappointment ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , he thought I was — younger than I was .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: smiling to himselfHow old are you , Belinda ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: dropping her eyesTwenty-two .After a pause .He thought I was eighteen . Such a disappointment !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: smiling openly at herBelinda , how old are you ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Just about the right age , Mr. Robinson .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: The right age for what ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: For this sort of conversation .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Shall I tell you how old you are ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Do you mean in figures or — poetically ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I meant —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Mr. Devenish said I was as old as the — now , I must get this the right way round — as old as the —

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I do n't want to talk about Mr. Devenish .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: with a sighNobody ever does — except Mr. Devenish . As old as the stars , and as young as the dawn .Settling herself cosily .I think that 's rather a nice age to be , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: A very nice age to be .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: It 's a pity he 's thrown me over for Delia ; I shall miss that sort of thing rather . You do n't say those sort of things about your aunt-in-law — not so often .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: eagerlyHe really is in love with Miss Robinson !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Oh yes . I expect he is out in the moonlight with her now , comparing her to Diana .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Well , that accounts for him . Now what about Baxter ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I thought I told you . Deeply disappointed to find that I was four years older than he expected , Mr. Baxter hurried from the drawing-room and buried himself in a column of the “ Encyclopedia Britannica . ”

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Well , that settles Baxter . Are there any more men in the neighbourhood ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: shaking her headIs n't it awful ? I 've only had those two for the last three weeks .

div.stage: TREMAYNE sits on the back of the sofa and looks down at her .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Belinda .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , Henry !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: My name is John .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , you never told me . I had to guess . Everybody thinks they can call me Belinda without giving me the least idea what their own names are . You were saying , John ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: My friends call me Jack .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Jack Robinson . That 's the man who always goes away so quickly . I hope you 're making more of a stay ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh , you maddening , maddening woman !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , I have to keep the conversation going . You do nothing but say “ Belinda . ”

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: taking her handHave you ever loved anybody seriously , Belinda ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I do n't ever do anything very seriously . The late Mr. Tremayne , my first husband — Jack — Is n't it funny , his name was Jack — he used to complain about it too sometimes .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: with convictionSilly ass !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Ah , I think you are a little hard on the late Mr. Tremayne .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Has he been dead long ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Dead to me .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: You quarrelled ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes . It was his fault entirely .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I 'm sure it was .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: How sweet of you to say that !

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Belinda , I want you to marry me and forget about him .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: happily to herselfThis is the proposal that those lamb cutlets interrupted this morning .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Belinda , I love you — do you understand ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Suppose my first husband turns up suddenly like — like E. A .?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Like who ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Well , like anybody .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: He wo n't — I know he wo n't . Do n't you love me enough to risk it , Belinda ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I have n't really said I love you at all yet .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Well , say it now .BELINDA looks at him , and then down again .You do ! Well , I 'm going to have a kiss , anyway ,He comes round the sofa and kisses her quickly .There !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: risingO-oh ! The late Mr. Tremayne never did that .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I have already told you that he was a silly ass .Sitting down on the sofaBelinda —

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , Henry — I mean , Jack ?

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Do you know who I am !He is thoroughly enjoying the surprise he is about to give her .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: noddingYes , Jack .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Jack Tremayne .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: jumping upGood heavens , you know !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: gentlyYes , Jack .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: angrilyYou 've known all the time that I was your husband , and you 've been playing with me and leading me on ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: mildlyWell , darling , you knew all the time that I was your wife , and you 've been making love to me and leading me on .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: That 's different .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: That 's just what the late Mr. Tremayne said , and then he slammed the door and went straight off to the Rocky Mountains and shot bears ; and I did n't see him again for eighteen years .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: remorsefullyDarling , I was a fool then , and I 'm a fool now .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I was a fool then , but I 'm not such a fool now — I 'm not going to let you go . It 's quite time I married and settled down .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: You darling ! How did you find out who I was ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: awkwardlyWell , it was rather curious , darling .After a pause .It was April , and I felt all sort of Aprily , and — and — there was the garden all full of daffodils — and — and there was Mr. Baxter — the one we left in the library — knowing all about moles . He 's probably got the M volume down now . Well , we were talking about them one day , and I happened to say that the late Mr. Tremayne — that was you , darling — had rather a peculiar one on his arm . And then he happened to see it this morning and told me about it .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: What an extraordinary story !

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , darling ; it 's really much more extraordinary than that . I think perhaps I 'd better tell you the rest of it another time .Coaxingly .Now show me where the nasty lion scratched you .TREMAYNE pulls up his sleeve .Oh !She kisses his arm .You should n't have left Chelsea , darling .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I should never have found you if I had n't .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: squeezing his armNo , Jack , you would n't .After a pause .I — I 've got another little surprise for you if — if you 're ready for it .Standing upProperly speaking , I ought to be wearing white . I shall certainly stand up while I 'm telling you .Modestly .Darling , we have a daughter — our little Delia .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Delia ? You said her name was Robinson .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Yes , darling , but you said yours was . One always takes one 's father 's name . Unless , of course , you were Lord Robinson .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: But you said her name was Robinson before you — oh , never mind about that . A daughter ? Belinda , how could you let me go and not tell me ?

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You forget how you 'd slammed the door . It is n't the sort of thing you shout through the window to a man on his way to America .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: taking her in his armsOh , Belinda , do n't let me ever go away again .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: I 'm not going to , Jack . I 'm going to settle down into a staid old married woman .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: Oh no , you 're not . You 're going on just as you did before . And I 'm going to propose to you every April , and win you , over all the other men in love with you .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: You darling !

div.stage: DELIA and DEVENISH come in from the garden .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: quietly to BELINDAOur daughter .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: going up to TREMAYNEYou 're my father .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: If you do n't mind very much , Delia .

sp.speaker: DELIA
sp.p: You 've been away a long time .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: I 'll do my best to make up for it .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: Delia , darling , I think you might kiss your poor old father .

div.stage: As the does to , DEVENISH suddenly and hastily kisses BELINDA on the cheek .

sp.speaker: DEVENISH
sp.p: Just in case you 're going to be my mother-in-law .

sp.speaker: TREMAYNE
sp.p: We seem to be rather a family party .

sp.speaker: BELINDA
sp.p: suddenlyThere ! We 've forgotten Mr. Baxter again .

sp.speaker: BAXTER
sp.p: who has come in quietly with a book in his handOh , do n't mind about me , Mrs. Tremayne . I 've enjoyed myself immensely .Referring to his book .I have been collecting some most valuable information onlooking round at themlunacy in the — er — county of Devonshire .

body.stage: THE RED FEATHERS

sp.speaker: AN OPERETTA IN ONE ACT
sp.p: In the living-room of a country-house , half farm , half manor , a MOTHER and her DAUGHTER are sitting . It is any year you please — between , let us say , the day when the fiddle first came to England and the day when Romance left it . As for the time of the year , let us call it May . Oh yes , it is certainly May , and about twelve o'clock , and the DAUGHTER is singing at the spinet , while her MOTHER is at her needlework . Through the lattice windows the murmur of a stream can be heard , on whose banks — but we shall come to that directly . Let us listen now to what the DAUGHTER is singing :Life passes by . I do not know its pleasure or its pain — The Spring was here , the Spring is here again , The Spring will die . Life passes by . The doors of Pain and Pleasure open wide , The crowd streams in — and I am left outside .... They know ; not I .

body.stage: You do n't like it ? Neither did her Mother .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: looking up from her workYes , I should call that a melancholy song , dear .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: It is sung by a melancholy person , Mother .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Why are you that , child ?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: getting upI want so much that I shall never have .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Well , so do we all .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: impatientlyOh , why does nothing ever happen ? We sit here all day , and we sing or do our embroidery , and we go to bed , and the next day we get up and do the same things over again , and so it goes on . Mother , is that all there is in the world ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: It 's all there is in our world .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Are we so very poor ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: We have the house — and very little else .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , I wish that we were really poor —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: You need n't wish , child .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , but I mean so that it would n't matter what clothes we wore ; so that we could wander over the hills and down into the valleys , and sleep perhaps in a barn and bathe ourselves in the brook next morning , and —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I do n't think I should like that very much . Perhaps I 'm peculiar .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , if only I were a boy to go out and make my own way in the world . Would you let me go , Mother , if I were a boy ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I do n't suppose you 'd ask me , dear .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: sighingOh , well ! We must make the best of it , I suppose . Perhaps one day something will happen .She goes back to the spinet and sings again .Lads and lasses , what will you sell , What will you sell ? Four stout walls and a roof atop , Warm fires gleaming brightly , Well-stored cellar and garnered crop , Money-bags packed tightly ; An ordered task in an ordered day , And a sure bed nightly ; Years which peacefully pass away , Until Death comes lightly . Lads and lasses , what will you buy ? What will you buy ? Here is a cap to cover your head , A cap with one red feather ; Here is a cloak to make your bed Warm or winter weather ; Here is a satchel to store your ware , Strongly lined with leather ; And here is a staff to take you there When you go forth together . Lads and lasses , what will you gain , What will you gain ? Chatter of rooks on tall elm-trees New Spring houses taking ; Daffodils in an April breeze Golden curtsies making ; Shadows of clouds across the weald From hill to valley breaking , The first faint stir which the woodlands yield When the world is waking . Lads and lasses , this is your gain , This is your gain .

body.stage: Towards the end of the song the face and shoulders of the TALKER appear at the open lattice window on the left . He listens with a bland and happy smile until the song is finished .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Brava ! Brava !They turn round towards the window in astonishment .A vastly pleasing song , vastly well sung . Mademoiselle Nightingale , permit me to felicitate you .Turning to the MotherThe Mother of the Nightingale also . Mon Dieu , what is voice , of a richness , of a purity ! To live with it always ! Madame , I felicitate you again .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I must ask you , sir , to explain the meaning of this intrusion .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Intrusion ? Oh , fie ! Madame , not intrusion . My feet stand upon the highway . The road , Madame , is common to all . I can quote you Rex — What does Rex , cap . 27 , para . 198 , say ? Via , says Rex , meaning the road ; communis is common ; omnibus to all , meaning thereby — but perchance I weary you ?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Mother , who is he ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Ah , Mademoiselle Nightingale , you may indeed ask . Who is he ? Is he the Pope of Rome ? Nay , he is not the Pope of Rome . Is he the Cham of Tartary ? Nay , he is not the Cham of Tartary , for an he were the Cham of Tartary —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I beg you , sir , to tell us as shortly as you can who you are and what you want .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Madam , by nature I am a taciturn man ; Silent John I am named by my friends . I am a glum body , a reserved creature . These things you will have already noticed . But now I will commit to you it secret , known only to my dearest friends . Uncommunicative as I am by naturehe disappears and reappears at the middle window, I am still more so when compelled to hold converse with two such ornaments of their sexhe disappears and reappears at the right-hand windowthrough a lattice window . Am I getting any nearer the door ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: resignedPray , sir , come in and tell us all about it . I see that we must have your tale .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: To be exact , Madame , I have two tails who follow me about everywhere . One is of my own poor sex , a man , a thing of whiskers ; the other has the honour to belong to that sex which — have I said it ?— you and Mademoiselle so adorn . Have I your ladyship 's permission ?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: eagerlyOh , Mother , let them come .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Well , I suppose I must have you all .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: with a bowMadame , I shall never forget this . Though I live to be ninety-three , this will always be engraved upon my memory . My grandchildren climbing upon my knee will wonder sometimes of what the old man is thinking . Little will they know — But I will attend you further within .He bows and disappears .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Mother , something is going to happen at last .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Oh , child , were you as weary as that ?

body.stage: The TALKER comes in at the door , followed by the SINGER and the FIDDLER . The SINGER is a pleasant-looking man of middle height , the FIDDLER a tall , silent girl . The TALKER himself is short and round , with a twinkling eye . Each wears a cap with a red feather in it .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Madame , your humble and most devoted servants . I have the honour to present to you her Royal Sweetness the Princess Carissima , His Flutiness the Duke of Bogota , and myself a mere Marquis .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , Mother , they 're wandering minstrels .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I bid you all welcome , sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Permit me to expound further . The Princess — a courtesy title bestowed by myself last Michaelmas Day — plays upon the fiddle with an unerring beauty which makes strong men weep . You shall hear her . I pray you have your handkerchers ready . His Flutiness the Duke — the title was granted last Candlemas — has a voice of a rare richness . He is cursed with a melancholy disposition most pleasing . He suffers from a surfeit of rejected love . A most waggish companion withal .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , what a shame !

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: You must not believe all that Johannes says , ladies .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I had already learnt that much , sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: For myself , I play upon the pipe . You shall hear .He plays “ cuckoo ” with an air .

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: The only notes he knows , ladies .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: indignantlyOh , fie , Sir , fie ! I protest , Madame , he maligns me . Have I not a G of surpassing splendour , of a fruitiness rarely encountered in this vale of tears ? Madame , you must hear my G. Now , where is it ?He arranges his fingers with great care on the pipe .I have it .He blows a G , and bows deeply first to MOTHER and then to DAUGHTER .

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: Marvellous !

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: to TALKERI thank you , Sir .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , Mother , is n't he splendid ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: to MOTHERWould you like my G again , Madame ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Not just now , I thank you , sir . Doubtless we shall feel more in need of it a little later on . But tell me , Sir , have you no other talent to match the singing and playing of your friends ?

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: He talks .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I had noticed it .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: This gift of talking with which her Royal Sweetness is good enough to credit me , irksome though it is to a man of silent habit like myself , a creature , as you will have noticed , of taciturn disposition ; this — I —FranklyMadame , I have lost that sentence . Have I your gracious permission to begin again ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I think it would be better , Sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Then , to put it shortly , Madame —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: If you could , sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: To be completely frank in this matter , Madame , I — er — go round with the hat . It is a sordid but necessary business .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: eagerlyOh , I hope they give you plenty of money .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Enough to support life , Mademoiselle . The hungry look which you observe upon His Flutiness is , as I have explained , due to melancholy .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: You are going to perform , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Of a surety , Mademoiselle . Perhaps I should add that for myself I am resting just now , and that my part of the performance will be limited to nothing more than a note or two upon the pipe .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: with a friendly smileSir , you are generous . We shall be glad to hear your friends .

body.stage: The TALKER bows and turns to his company .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: A song , good Master Duke , a song which her Royal Sweetness will accompany upon the fiddle . Let it end , I pray you , with a G , so that I may bring the thing to a climax upon the last note .

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: to SINGERMorland Hill .

lg.l: You like that ?
Very well .
Oh , when the wind is in the North ,
I take my staff and sally forth ;
And when it whistles from the East
I do not mind it in the least ;
The warm wind murmurs through the trees
Its messages from Southern seas ;
But after all perhaps the best
Is that which whispers from the West .
Oh let the wind , the wind be what it will ,
So long as I may walk on Morland Hill !
The staff which helps to carry me ,
I cut it from the Hazel-tree ;
But once I had a cudgel torn
Most circumspectly from the Thorn ;
I know a fellow , far from rash ,
Who swears entirely by the Ash ;
And all good travellers invoke
A blessing on the mighty Oak .
Oh let the wood , the wood be what it will ,
So long as I may walk on Morland Hill !
Some years ago I gave my heart
To Prue until we had to part ;
Then , seeing Susan 's pretty face ,
I left it with her for a space ;
And Susan had my heart until
I wanted it for Mistress Jill ;
I think , although I am not clear ,
That Chloe 's had it this last year .
Oh let the wench , the wench be whom you will ,
So long as I may walk on Morland Hill !

body.stage: The TALKER comes in proudly on the last note and takes most of the applause .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: I 'm not sure that I like that last verse .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Oh , you must n't believe all he sings . A cursed melancholy fellow by nature . But waggish — waggish withal .

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: to DAUGHTERWe have to sing what the poets write for us , Mademoiselle . Had I written a song myself , it had been about one woman only .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: And there would have been a hundred and twenty-five verses to it .

lg.l: Your song was well sung , sir ; I thank you for it .
Will you not play us something now ?

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: If you wish it .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: You would wish me to accompany her , of course .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: with a smileIt is kind of you , sir , but I think perhaps my daughter —

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: eagerlyYes , of course , I will if I can .She goes to the spinet .

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: playing a few notesDo you know this ?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Yes , I think so .She plays . At the end of it the TALKER finds himself bowing to the applause .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: And now , Madame , you have had a sample of all our poor talents , save and except that paltry talent of mine which in other company concludes such a performance . I pray you tell me what you think of the entertainment .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I have enjoyed it immensely , good Master Johannes . And if you did wish to exercise that talent of yours , of which so far we have only heard —

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Nay , nay , Madame , I beg you .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Then , Sir , I offer you my grateful thanks for your entertainment .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: And I too .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Ladies , you are too kind — er —he hesitates— er —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: , The fact is , Madame , that now we approach or , so to speak , draw nigh or adjacent — in other words , Madame , we are perilously approximate —

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: Tell her straight out .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Tell her what ?

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: What we 've come for .

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: Master Johannes , Madam , is so accustomed when he goes round with the hat to disguise under it flow of words the fact that money is as necessary to an artist as applause , that he has lost the habit of saying anything in less than ten sentences .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: mournfullyAnd yet I am a taciturn man .

sp.speaker: MOWER
sp.p: Well , will somebody tell me , for I confess I have been wondering what is behind it all .

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: Tell her , Johannes .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: If you will allow me , Madame . But tell me first , did you notice anything lacking in our performance ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: surprisedNo ; I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: to DAUGHTERPerhaps you , Mademoiselle ?

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: shylyIt seemed to lack a woman 's voice , sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: admiringlyWhat intelligence ! What profundity !To MOTHERMadam , I felicitate you again on your daughter . Unerringly she has laid her finger on the weak joint in our armour . We have no woman 's voice .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Well , Sir , I do n't see how I can help you .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Madame , you have a nightingale . It has lived in a cage all its life . It looks through the bars sometimes , and sees the great world outside , and sighs and turns back to its business of singing . Madame , it would sing better outside in the open air , with the other birds .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I do n't understand you , sir . Are you referring to my daughter ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: looking towards the windowThere is a stream which runs beyond the road , with a green bank to it . We were seated on that bank , I and my two companions , eating our bread and cheese , and washing it down with draughts from that good stream . We were tired , for we had come from over the hills that morning , and it was good to lie on our backs there and watch the little clouds taking shape after shape in the blue , and so to dream our dreams . In a little while the road would take us westward , here through a wood banked with primroses , there across a common or between high spring hedges with the little stream babbling ever at the side of us . And in the evening we would come to an inn , where there would be good company , and we would sing and play to them , and they would reward us .With a shrugIt is a pleasant life .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: eagerlyOh , go on !

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Yes , go on , Sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: We were lying on our backs thus , Madame , when we heard the nightingale . “ Duke , ” says I , “ it is early yet for the nightingale . ” His Flutiness removes his cap from his face , takes a squint at the sun , and says “ Monstrous early , good Master Johannes , ” and claps his cap back again . “ What says you , Fiddler , ” says I , “ in this matter of nightingales ? Is it possible , ” says I ; “ the sun being where it is , and nightingales being what they are — to wit , nightingales ? ” “ It 's not a nightingale , ” says Fiddler dreamily , “ it 's a girl . ” “ Then , ” says I , jumping up , “ it is a girl we want . She must put the red feather in her cap , and come her ways with us . ”With a bowMadame , your humble servant .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Oh , Mother , you will let me go , wo n't you ? I must , I must ! He is quite right . I 'm caged here . Oh , you will let me see something of the world before I grow old !

sp.speaker: FIDDLER
sp.p: suddenlyYes , let her come . If she feels like that , she ought to come .

sp.speaker: SINGER
sp.p: with a very winning smileWe will take great care of her , Madame , as if she were our own sister .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: surprisingly to JOHANNESWhat do you think of cider as a drink , Master Johannes ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: who had not expected it , but is always readyCider — ah , there 's a drink ! Oh , I can talk to you about cider , glum body as I am by nature , having been as it were taciturn from birth . Yet of cider I could talk you —

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Ours is considered very good cider .To her daughterTake them , child , and give them such refreshment as they want . They have deserved it for their entertainment .

sp.speaker: DAUGHTER
sp.p: Why , of course , Mother . Come this way please .

body.stage: She leads the way , and the others follow , the TALKER coming last and murmuring “ Cider ” to himself .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Master Johannes .He turns round .A word with you , if you please , sir .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: But certainly , Madame . The cider will be all the better for the expectation .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Sit down , please .He does so .Master Johannes , who are you , all of you ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: I thought I had explained , Madame . Her Royal Sweetness Princess Carissima , His Flutiness the Duke of Bogota , and myself a humble Marquis . We may be referred to collectively as the Red Feathers . For myself I am sometimes called Silent John , being of a close disposition .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: Whatever you are called , you are , I think , a man of the world , and you will understand that if I am to trust my daughter to you , for however little a time , I must know something more about you .

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: Madame , I will make a confession to you , a confession I have never yet made to man , woman , or child . I am forty-six years of age ; it is , in fact , my birthday . Were I to begin to tell you something about myself , starting from that day , forty-six years ago , when I was born — were I to begin — well , Madame , I am only too ready to begin . It is a subject I find vastly pleasant . But ,looking at her comicallyshall I begin ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: with a smileWould you make it so long a story , sir ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
sp.p: with a sighThe tongue is an unruly member , and to one who has but three notes on the pipe , and yet desires to express himself , talking is a great comfort .

sp.speaker: MOTHER
sp.p: I said you were a man of the world , sir . May I say now that I think you must be a man of our world ?

sp.speaker: TALKER
